element.definition: Parent product (if any).
element.comment: For products that have multiple collections. For example Peripheral Blood Stem Cells may be collected over several days from a single donor and the donation split into in multiple containers which must be linked to the parent donation.

element.name: collection
element.definition: How this product was collected.

element.name: processing
element.description: Any processing of the product during collection
element.definition: Any processing of the product during collection that does not change the fundamental nature of the product. For example adding anti-coagulants during the collection of Peripheral Blood Stem Cells.

element.name: manipulation
element.definition: Any manipulation of product post-collection that is intended to alter the product. For example a buffy-coat enrichment or CD8 reduction of Peripheral Blood Stem Cells to make it more suitable for infusion.

element.name: storage
element.definition: Product storage.

element.name: collector
element.definition: Healthcare professional who is performing the collection.

element.name: source
element.definition: The patient or entity, such as a hospital or vendor in the case of a processed/manipulated/manufactured product, providing the product.

element.name: collected
element.definition: Time of product collection.

element.name: description
element.definition: Description of manipulation.

element.name: time
element.definition: Time of manipulation.

element.name: description
element.definition: Description of of processing.

element.name: procedure
element.definition: Procesing code.

binding.name: BiologicallyDerivedProductProcedure
binding.description: Biologically Derived Product Procedure.

element.name: additive
element.definition: Substance added during processing.

element.name: time
element.definition: Time of processing.

element.name: description
element.definition: Description of storage.

element.name: temperature
element.definition: Storage temperature.

element.name: scale
element.definition: Temperature scale used.

binding.name: BiologicallyDerivedProductStorageScale
binding.description: BiologicallyDerived Product Storage Scale.

element.name: duration
element.definition: Storage timeperiod.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: Identifier for this instance of the anatomical structure.

element.name: active
element.description: Whether this record is in active use
element.definition: Whether this body site is in active use.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because it may be used to mark that the resource was created in error.

element.name: morphology
element.definition: The kind of structure being represented by the body structure at `BodyStructure.location`. This can define both normal and abnormal morphologies.
element.comment: The minimum cardinality of 0 supports the use case of specifying a location without defining a morphology.

binding.name: BodyStructureCode
binding.description: Codes describing anatomic morphology.

element.name: location
element.definition: The anatomical location or region of the specimen, lesion, or body structure.

binding.name: BodySite
binding.description: Codes describing anatomical locations. May include laterality.

element.name: locationQualifier
element.definition: Qualifier to refine the anatomical location. These include qualifiers for laterality, relative location, directionality, number, and plane.

binding.name: BodyStructureQualifier
binding.description: Concepts modifying the anatomic location.

element.name: description
element.definition: A summary, characterization or explanation of the body structure.
element.comment: This description could include any visual markings used to orientate the viewer e.g. external reference points, special sutures, ink markings.

element.name: image
element.definition: Image or images used to identify a location.

element.name: patient
element.definition: The person to which the body site belongs.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: A persistent identifier for the bundle that won't change as a bundle is copied from server to server.
element.comment: Persistent identity generally only matters for batches of type Document, Message, and Collection. It would not normally be populated for search and history results and servers ignore Bundle.identifier when processing batches and transactions. For Documents the .identifier SHALL be populated such that the .identifier is globally unique.

element.name: type
element.description: document | message | transaction | transaction-response | batch | batch-response | history | searchset | collection
element.definition: Indicates the purpose of this bundle - how it is intended to be used.
element.comment: It's possible to use a bundle for other purposes (e.g. a document can be accepted as a transaction). This is primarily defined so that there can be specific rules for some of the bundle types.

binding.name: BundleType
binding.description: Indicates the purpose of a bundle - how it is intended to be used.

element.name: timestamp
element.definition: The date/time that the bundle was assembled - i.e. when the resources were placed in the bundle.
element.comment:
For many bundles, the timestamp is equal to .meta.lastUpdated, because they are not stored (e.g. search results). When a bundle is placed in a persistent store, .meta.lastUpdated will be usually be changed by the server. When the bundle is a message, a middleware agent altering the message (even if not stored) SHOULD update .meta.lastUpdated. .timestamp is used to track the original time of the Bundle, and SHOULD be populated.
Usage:
* document : the date the document was created. Note: the composition may predate the document, or be associated with multiple documents. The date of the composition - the authoring time - may be earlier than the document assembly time * message : the date that the content of the message was assembled. This date is not changed by middleware engines unless they add additional data that changes the meaning of the time of the message * history : the date that the history was assembled. This time would be used as the _since time to ask for subsequent updates * searchset : the time that the search set was assembled. Note that different pages MAY have different timestamps but need not. Having different timestamps does not imply that subsequent pages will represent or include changes made since the initial query * transaction | transaction-response | batch | batch-response | collection : no particular assigned meaning
The timestamp value should be greater than the lastUpdated and other timestamps in the resources in the bundle, and it should be equal or earlier than the .meta.lastUpdated on the Bundle itself.

element.name: total
element.description: If search, the total number of matches
element.definition: If a set of search matches, this is the total number of entries of type 'match' across all pages in the search. It does not include search.mode = 'include' or 'outcome' entries and it does not provide a count of the number of entries in the Bundle.
element.comment: Only used if the bundle is a search result set. The total does not include resources such as OperationOutcome and included resources, only the total number of matching resources.

element.name: link
element.definition: A series of links that provide context to this bundle.
element.comment:
Both Bundle.link and Bundle.entry.link are defined to support providing additional context when Bundles are used (e.g. [HATEOAS](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HATEOAS)).
Bundle.entry.link corresponds to links found in the HTTP header if the resource in the entry was [read](http.html#read) directly.
This specification defines some specific uses of Bundle.link for [searching](search.html#conformance) and [paging](http.html#paging), but no specific uses for Bundle.entry.link, and no defined function in a transaction - the meaning is implementation specific.

element.name: entry
element.description: Entry in the bundle - will have a resource or information
element.definition: An entry in a bundle resource - will either contain a resource or information about a resource (transactions and history only).

constraint.name: bdl-8
constraint.message: fullUrl cannot be a version specific reference

constraint.name: bdl-5
constraint.message: must be a resource unless there's a request or response

element.name: signature
element.definition: Digital Signature - base64 encoded. XML-DSig or a JWT.
element.comment: The signature could be created by the "author" of the bundle or by the originating device. Requirements around inclusion of a signature, verification of signatures and treatment of signed/non-signed bundles is implementation-environment specific.

element.name: link
element.definition: A series of links that provide context to this entry.

element.name: fullUrl
element.description: URI for resource (Absolute URL server address or URI for UUID/OID)
element.definition: The Absolute URL for the resource. The fullUrl SHALL NOT disagree with the id in the resource - i.e. if the fullUrl is not a urn:uuid, the URL shall be version-independent URL consistent with the Resource.id. The fullUrl is a version independent reference to the resource. The fullUrl element SHALL have a value except that: * fullUrl can be empty on a POST (although it does not need to when specifying a temporary id for reference in the bundle) * Results from operations might involve resources that are not identified.
element.comment:
fullUrl might not be [unique in the context of a resource](bundle.html#bundle-unique). Note that since [FHIR resources do not need to be served through the FHIR API](references.html), the fullURL might be a URN or an absolute URL that does not end with the logical id of the resource (Resource.id). However, but if the fullUrl does look like a RESTful server URL (e.g. meets the [regex](references.html#regex), then the 'id' portion of the fullUrl SHALL end with the Resource.id.
Note that the fullUrl is not the same as the canonical URL - it's an absolute url for an endpoint serving the resource (these will happen to have the same value on the canonical server for the resource with the canonical URL).

element.name: resource
element.definition: The Resource for the entry. The purpose/meaning of the resource is determined by the Bundle.type.

element.name: search
element.definition: Information about the search process that lead to the creation of this entry.

element.name: request
element.definition: Additional information about how this entry should be processed as part of a transaction or batch. For history, it shows how the entry was processed to create the version contained in the entry.

element.name: response
element.definition: Indicates the results of processing the corresponding 'request' entry in the batch or transaction being responded to or what the results of an operation where when returning history.

element.name: method
element.description: GET | HEAD | POST | PUT | DELETE | PATCH
element.definition: In a transaction or batch, this is the HTTP action to be executed for this entry. In a history bundle, this indicates the HTTP action that occurred.

binding.name: HTTPVerb
binding.description: HTTP verbs (in the HTTP command line). See [HTTP rfc](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231) for details.

element.name: url
element.description: URL for HTTP equivalent of this entry
element.definition: The URL for this entry, relative to the root (the address to which the request is posted).
element.comment: E.g. for a Patient Create, the method would be "POST" and the URL would be "Patient". For a Patient Update, the method would be PUT and the URL would be "Patient/[id]".

element.name: ifNoneMatch
element.definition: If the ETag values match, return a 304 Not Modified status. See the API documentation for ["Conditional Read"](http.html#cread).

element.name: ifModifiedSince
element.definition: Only perform the operation if the last updated date matches. See the API documentation for ["Conditional Read"](http.html#cread).

element.name: ifMatch
element.definition: Only perform the operation if the Etag value matches. For more information, see the API section ["Managing Resource Contention"](http.html#concurrency).

element.name: ifNoneExist
element.definition: Instruct the server not to perform the create if a specified resource already exists. For further information, see the API documentation for ["Conditional Create"](http.html#ccreate). This is just the query portion of the URL - what follows the "?" (not including the "?").

element.name: status
element.definition: The status code returned by processing this entry. The status SHALL start with a 3 digit HTTP code (e.g. 404) and may contain the standard HTTP description associated with the status code.

element.name: location
element.description: The location (if the operation returns a location)
element.definition: The location header created by processing this operation, populated if the operation returns a location.

element.name: etag
element.description: The Etag for the resource (if relevant)
element.definition: The Etag for the resource, if the operation for the entry produced a versioned resource (see [Resource Metadata and Versioning](http.html#versioning) and [Managing Resource Contention](http.html#concurrency)).
element.comment: Etags match the Resource.meta.versionId. The ETag has to match the version id in the header if a resource is included.

element.name: lastModified
element.definition: The date/time that the resource was modified on the server.
element.comment: This has to match the same time in the meta header (meta.lastUpdated) if a resource is included.

element.name: outcome
element.description: OperationOutcome with hints and warnings (for batch/transaction)
element.definition: An OperationOutcome containing hints and warnings produced as part of processing this entry in a batch or transaction.
element.comment:
For a POST/PUT operation, this is the equivalent outcome that would be returned for prefer = operationoutcome - except that the resource is always returned whether or not the outcome is returned.
This outcome is not used for error responses in batch/transaction, only for hints and warnings. In a batch operation, the error will be in Bundle.entry.response, and for transaction, there will be a single OperationOutcome instead of a bundle in the case of an error.

element.name: mode
element.description: match | include | outcome - why this is in the result set
element.definition: Why this entry is in the result set - whether it's included as a match or because of an _include requirement, or to convey information or warning information about the search process.
element.comment: There is only one mode. In some corner cases, a resource may be included because it is both a match and an include. In these circumstances, 'match' takes precedence.

binding.name: SearchEntryMode
binding.description: Why an entry is in the result set - whether it's included as a match or because of an _include requirement, or to convey information or warning information about the search process.

element.name: score
element.definition: When searching, the server's search ranking score for the entry.
element.comment:
Servers are not required to return a ranking score. 1 is most relevant, and 0 is least relevant. Often, search results are sorted by score, but the client may specify a different sort order.
See [Patient Match](patient-operation-match.html) for the EMPI search which relates to this element.

element.name: relation
element.definition: A name which details the functional use for this link - see [http://www.iana.org/assignments/link-relations/link-relations.xhtml#link-relations-1](http://www.iana.org/assignments/link-relations/link-relations.xhtml#link-relations-1).

element.name: url
element.definition: The reference details for the link.

element.name: url
element.description: Canonical identifier for this capability statement, represented as a URI (globally unique)
element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this capability statement when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which at which an authoritative instance of this capability statement is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the capability statement is stored on different servers.
element.comment:
Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid: but real http: addresses are preferred. Multiple instances may share the same URL if they have a distinct version.
The determination of when to create a new version of a resource (same url, new version) vs. defining a new artifact is up to the author. Considerations for making this decision are found in [Technical and Business Versions](resource.html#versions).
In some cases, the resource can no longer be found at the stated url, but the url itself cannot change. Implementations can use the [meta.source](resource.html#meta) element to indicate where the current master source of the resource can be found.

element.name: version
element.description: Business version of the capability statement
element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the capability statement when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the capability statement author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence.
element.comment: There may be different capability statement instances that have the same identifier but different versions. The version can be appended to the url in a reference to allow a reference to a particular business version of the capability statement with the format [url]|[version].

element.name: name
element.description: Name for this capability statement (computer friendly)
element.definition: A natural language name identifying the capability statement. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alphanumeric type name to ensure that it is machine-processing friendly.

element.name: title
element.description: Name for this capability statement (human friendly)
element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the capability statement.
element.comment: This name does not need to be machine-processing friendly and may contain punctuation, white-space, etc.

element.name: status
element.definition: The status of this capability statement. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content.
element.comment: Allows filtering of capability statements that are appropriate for use versus not.This is not intended for use with actual capability statements, but where capability statements are used to describe possible or desired systems.

binding.name: PublicationStatus
binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.name: experimental
element.description: For testing purposes, not real usage
element.definition: A Boolean value to indicate that this capability statement is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing) and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.comment: Allows filtering of capability statements that are appropriate for use versus not.

element.name: date
element.definition: The date (and optionally time) when the capability statement was published. The date must change when the business version changes and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the capability statement changes.
element.comment: Note that this is not the same as the resource last-modified-date, since the resource may be a secondary representation of the capability statement. Additional specific dates may be added as extensions or be found by consulting Provenances associated with past versions of the resource.

element.name: publisher
element.description: Name of the publisher (organization or individual)
element.definition: The name of the organization or individual that published the capability statement.
element.comment: Usually an organization but may be an individual. The publisher (or steward) of the capability statement is the organization or individual primarily responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the capability statement. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the capability statement. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.

element.name: contact
element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
element.comment: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number, etc.

element.name: description
element.description: Natural language description of the capability statement
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the capability statement from a consumer's perspective. Typically, this is used when the capability statement describes a desired rather than an actual solution, for example as a formal expression of requirements as part of an RFP.
element.comment: This description can be used to capture details such as why the capability statement was built, comments about misuse, instructions for clinical use and interpretation, literature references, examples from the paper world, etc. It is not a rendering of the capability statement as conveyed in the 'text' field of the resource itself. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context (e.g. the language of the capability statement is presumed to be the predominant language in the place the capability statement was created).This does not need to be populated if the description is adequately implied by the software or implementation details.

element.name: useContext
element.description: The context that the content is intended to support
element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate capability statement instances.
element.comment: When multiple useContexts are specified, there is no expectation that all or any of the contexts apply.

element.name: jurisdiction
element.description: Intended jurisdiction for capability statement (if applicable)
element.definition: A legal or geographic region in which the capability statement is intended to be used.
element.comment: It may be possible for the capability statement to be used in jurisdictions other than those for which it was originally designed or intended.

binding.name: Jurisdiction
binding.description: Countries and regions within which this artifact is targeted for use.

element.name: purpose
element.description: Why this capability statement is defined
element.definition: Explanation of why this capability statement is needed and why it has been designed as it has.
element.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the capability statement. Instead, it provides traceability of ''why'' the resource is either needed or ''why'' it is defined as it is. This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this capability statement.

element.name: copyright
element.definition: A copyright statement relating to the capability statement and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the capability statement.

element.name: kind
element.definition: The way that this statement is intended to be used, to describe an actual running instance of software, a particular product (kind, not instance of software) or a class of implementation (e.g. a desired purchase).

binding.name: CapabilityStatementKind
binding.description: How a capability statement is intended to be used.

element.name: instantiates
element.description: Canonical URL of another capability statement this implements
element.definition: Reference to a canonical URL of another CapabilityStatement that this software implements. This capability statement is a published API description that corresponds to a business service. The server may actually implement a subset of the capability statement it claims to implement, so the capability statement must specify the full capability details.
element.comment:
HL7 defines the following Services: [Terminology Service](terminology-service.html).
Many [Implementation Guides](http://fhir.org/guides/registry) define additional services.

element.name: imports
element.description: Canonical URL of another capability statement this adds to
element.definition: Reference to a canonical URL of another CapabilityStatement that this software adds to. The capability statement automatically includes everything in the other statement, and it is not duplicated, though the server may repeat the same resources, interactions and operations to add additional details to them.
element.comment:
the contents of any directly or indirectly imported CapabilityStatements SHALL NOT overlap, i.e. they cannot refer to the same rest/resource, operations/name, searchparam/name, interaction/code, messaging/endpoint, document/mode pair.
A capability statement that imports another CapabilityStatement automatically instantiates it too (though this is often not a very useful statement for the kinds of CapabilityStatements that are suitable for importing).

element.name: software
element.description: Software that is covered by this capability statement
element.definition: Software that is covered by this capability statement. It is used when the capability statement describes the capabilities of a particular software version, independent of an installation.

element.name: implementation
element.description: If this describes a specific instance
element.definition: Identifies a specific implementation instance that is described by the capability statement - i.e. a particular installation, rather than the capabilities of a software program.

element.name: fhirVersion
element.definition: The version of the FHIR specification that this CapabilityStatement describes (which SHALL be the same as the FHIR version of the CapabilityStatement itself). There is no default value.
element.comment: Servers may implement multiple versions (see [Managing Multiple Versions](versioning.html), and the [$versions](capabilitystatement-operation-versions.html) operation). If they do, and the CapabilityStatement is requested from the server, then this fhirVersion will be either the version requested, or the server's default version.

binding.name: FHIRVersion
binding.description: All published FHIR Versions.

element.name: format
element.description: formats supported (xml | json | ttl | mime type)
element.definition: A list of the formats supported by this implementation using their content types.
element.comment: "xml", "json" and "ttl" are allowed, which describe the simple encodings described in the specification (and imply appropriate bundle support). Otherwise, mime types are legal here.

binding.name: MimeType
binding.description: The mime type of an attachment. Any valid mime type is allowed.

element.name: patchFormat
element.definition: A list of the patch formats supported by this implementation using their content types.
element.comment: At present, the patch mime types application/json-patch+json and application/xml-patch+xml are legal. Generally, if a server supports PATCH, it would be expected to support the patch formats and match the formats it supports, but this is not always possible or necessary.

binding.name: MimeType
binding.description: The mime type of an attachment. Any valid mime type is allowed.

element.name: implementationGuide
element.definition: A list of implementation guides that the server does (or should) support in their entirety.

element.name: rest
element.description: If the endpoint is a RESTful one
element.definition: A definition of the restful capabilities of the solution, if any.
element.comment: Multiple repetitions allow definition of both client and/or server behaviors or possibly behaviors under different configuration settings (for software or requirements statements).

constraint.name: cpb-9
constraint.message: A given resource can only be described once per RESTful mode.

element.name: messaging
element.definition: A description of the messaging capabilities of the solution.
element.comment: Multiple repetitions allow the documentation of multiple endpoints per solution.

element.name: document
element.definition: A document definition.

element.name: mode
element.definition: Mode of this document declaration - whether an application is a producer or consumer.

binding.name: DocumentMode
binding.description: Whether the application produces or consumes documents.

element.name: documentation
element.definition: A description of how the application supports or uses the specified document profile. For example, when documents are created, what action is taken with consumed documents, etc.

element.name: profile
element.description: Constraint on the resources used in the document
element.definition: A profile on the document Bundle that constrains which resources are present, and their contents.
element.comment: The profile is actually on the Bundle.

element.name: description
element.definition: Information about the specific installation that this capability statement relates to.

element.name: url
element.definition: An absolute base URL for the implementation. This forms the base for REST interfaces as well as the mailbox and document interfaces.

element.name: custodian
element.definition: The organization responsible for the management of the instance and oversight of the data on the server at the specified URL.

element.name: endpoint
element.definition: An endpoint (network accessible address) to which messages and/or replies are to be sent.

element.name: reliableCache
element.definition: Length if the receiver's reliable messaging cache in minutes (if a receiver) or how long the cache length on the receiver should be (if a sender).
element.comment: If this value is missing then the application does not implement (receiver) or depend on (sender) reliable messaging.

element.name: documentation
element.definition: Documentation about the system's messaging capabilities for this endpoint not otherwise documented by the capability statement. For example, the process for becoming an authorized messaging exchange partner.

element.name: supportedMessage
element.definition: References to message definitions for messages this system can send or receive.
element.comment: This is a proposed alternative to the messaging.event structure.

element.name: protocol
element.definition: A list of the messaging transport protocol(s) identifiers, supported by this endpoint.

binding.name: MessageTransport
binding.description: The protocol used for message transport.

element.name: address
element.description: Network address or identifier of the end-point
element.definition: The network address of the endpoint. For solutions that do not use network addresses for routing, it can be just an identifier.

element.name: mode
element.definition: The mode of this event declaration - whether application is sender or receiver.

binding.name: EventCapabilityMode
binding.description: The mode of a message capability statement.

element.name: definition
element.definition: Points to a message definition that identifies the messaging event, message structure, allowed responses, etc.

element.name: mode
element.definition: Identifies whether this portion of the statement is describing the ability to initiate or receive restful operations.

binding.name: RestfulCapabilityMode
binding.description: The mode of a RESTful capability statement.

element.name: documentation
element.definition: Information about the system's restful capabilities that apply across all applications, such as security.

element.name: security
element.definition: Information about security implementation from an interface perspective - what a client needs to know.

element.name: resource
element.description: Resource served on the REST interface
element.definition: A specification of the restful capabilities of the solution for a specific resource type.
element.comment: Max of one repetition per resource type.

constraint.name: cpb-12
constraint.message: Search parameter names must be unique in the context of a resource.

element.name: interaction
element.definition: A specification of restful operations supported by the system.

element.name: searchParam
element.description: Search parameters for searching all resources
element.definition: Search parameters that are supported for searching all resources for implementations to support and/or make use of - either references to ones defined in the specification, or additional ones defined for/by the implementation.
element.comment: Typically, the only search parameters supported for all searches are those that apply to all resources - tags, profiles, text search etc. These search parameters should include the control search parameters such as _sort, _count, etc. that also apply to this resource (though many will be listed at [CapabilityStatement.rest.searchParam](capabilitystatement-definitions.html#CapabilityStatement.rest.searchParam)). The behavior of some search parameters may be further described by other code or extension elements, or narrative within the capability statement or linked [SearchParameter](searchparameter.html#) definitions.

element.name: operation
element.description: Definition of a system level operation
element.definition: Definition of an operation or a named query together with its parameters and their meaning and type.
element.comment: CapabilityStatement.rest.operation is for operations invoked at the system level, or for operations that are supported across multiple resource types. Operations linked from CapabilityStatement.rest.operation must have OperationDefinition.system = true, or more than one Operation.resource.

element.name: compartment
element.definition: An absolute URI which is a reference to the definition of a compartment that the system supports. The reference is to a CompartmentDefinition resource by its canonical URL .
element.comment: At present, the only defined compartments are at [CompartmentDefinition](compartmentdefinition.html).

element.name: code
element.definition: A coded identifier of the operation, supported by the system.

binding.name: SystemRestfulInteraction
binding.description: Operations supported by REST at the system level.

element.name: documentation
element.definition: Guidance specific to the implementation of this operation, such as limitations on the kind of transactions allowed, or information about system wide search is implemented.

element.name: type
element.description: A resource type that is supported
element.definition: A type of resource exposed via the restful interface.

binding.name: ResourceType
binding.description: One of the resource types defined as part of this version of FHIR.

element.name: profile
element.description: Base System profile for all uses of resource
element.definition: A specification of the profile that describes the solution's overall support for the resource, including any constraints on cardinality, bindings, lengths or other limitations. See further discussion in [Using Profiles](profiling.html#profile-uses).
element.comment: The profile applies to all resources of this type - i.e. it is the superset of what is supported by the system.

element.name: supportedProfile
element.definition: A list of profiles that represent different use cases supported by the system. For a server, "supported by the system" means the system hosts/produces a set of resources that are conformant to a particular profile, and allows clients that use its services to search using this profile and to find appropriate data. For a client, it means the system will search by this profile and process data according to the guidance implicit in the profile. See further discussion in [Using Profiles](profiling.html#profile-uses).
element.comment: Supported profiles are different than the profile that applies to a particular resource in .rest.resource.profile. The resource profile is a general statement of what features of the resource are supported overall by the system - the sum total of the facilities it supports. A supported profile is a deeper statement about the functionality of the data and services provided by the server (or used by the client). A typical case is a laboratory system that produces a set of different reports - this is the list of types of data that it publishes. A key aspect of declaring profiles here is the question of how the client converts knowledge that the server publishes this data into working with the data; the client can inspect individual resources to determine whether they conform to a particular profile, but how does it find the ones that do? It does so by searching using the _profile parameter, so any resources listed here must be valid values for the _profile resource (using the identifier in the target profile).

element.name: documentation
element.description: Additional information about the use of the resource type
element.definition: Additional information about the resource type used by the system.

element.name: interaction
element.definition: Identifies a restful operation supported by the solution.
element.comment: In general, a Resource will only appear in a CapabilityStatement if the server actually has some capabilities - e.g. there is at least one interaction supported. However interactions can be omitted to support summarization (_summary = true).

element.name: versioning
element.definition: This field is set to no-version to specify that the system does not support (server) or use (client) versioning for this resource type. If this has some other value, the server must at least correctly track and populate the versionId meta-property on resources. If the value is 'versioned-update', then the server supports all the versioning features, including using e-tags for version integrity in the API.
element.comment: If a server supports versionIds correctly, it SHOULD support vread too, but is not required to do so.

binding.name: ResourceVersionPolicy
binding.description: How the system supports versioning for a resource.

element.name: readHistory
element.description: Whether vRead can return past versions
element.definition: A flag for whether the server is able to return past versions as part of the vRead operation.
element.comment: It is useful to support the vRead operation for current operations, even if past versions aren't available.

element.name: updateCreate
element.description: If update can commit to a new identity
element.definition: A flag to indicate that the server allows or needs to allow the client to create new identities on the server (that is, the client PUTs to a location where there is no existing resource). Allowing this operation means that the server allows the client to create new identities on the server.
element.comment: Allowing the clients to create new identities on the server means that the system administrator needs to have confidence that the clients do not create clashing identities between them. Obviously, if there is only one client, this won't happen. While creating identities on the client means that the clients need to be managed, it's much more convenient for many scenarios if such management can be put in place.

element.name: conditionalCreate
element.definition: A flag that indicates that the server supports conditional create.
element.comment: Conditional Create is mainly appropriate for interface engine scripts converting from other formats, such as v2.

element.name: conditionalRead
element.definition: A code that indicates how the server supports conditional read.
element.comment: Conditional Read is mainly appropriate for interface engine scripts converting from other formats, such as v2.

binding.name: ConditionalReadStatus
binding.description: A code that indicates how the server supports conditional read.

element.name: conditionalUpdate
element.definition: A flag that indicates that the server supports conditional update.
element.comment: Conditional Update is mainly appropriate for interface engine scripts converting from other formats, such as v2.

element.name: conditionalDelete
element.description: not-supported | single | multiple - how conditional delete is supported
element.definition: A code that indicates how the server supports conditional delete.
element.comment: Conditional Delete is mainly appropriate for interface engine scripts converting from other formats, such as v2.

binding.name: ConditionalDeleteStatus
binding.description: A code that indicates how the server supports conditional delete.

element.name: referencePolicy
element.definition: A set of flags that defines how references are supported.

binding.name: ReferenceHandlingPolicy
binding.description: A set of flags that defines how references are supported.

element.name: searchInclude
element.definition: A list of _include values supported by the server.
element.comment: If this list is empty, the server does not support includes.

element.name: searchRevInclude
element.definition: A list of _revinclude (reverse include) values supported by the server.
element.comment: If this list is empty, the server does not support reverse includes.

element.name: searchParam
element.definition: Search parameters for implementations to support and/or make use of - either references to ones defined in the specification, or additional ones defined for/by the implementation.
element.comment: The search parameters should include the control search parameters such as _sort, _count, etc. that also apply to this resource (though many will be listed at [CapabilityStatement.rest.searchParam](capabilitystatement-definitions.html#CapabilityStatement.rest.searchParam)). The behavior of some search parameters may be further described by other code or extension elements, or narrative within the capability statement or linked [SearchParameter](searchparameter.html#) definitions.

element.name: operation
element.definition: Definition of an operation or a named query together with its parameters and their meaning and type. Consult the definition of the operation for details about how to invoke the operation, and the parameters.
element.comment:
Operations linked from CapabilityStatement.rest.resource.operation must have OperationDefinition.type = true or OperationDefinition.instance = true.
If an operation that is listed in multiple CapabilityStatement.rest.resource.operation (e.g. for different resource types), then clients should understand that the operation is only supported on the specified resource types, and that may be a subset of those listed in OperationDefinition.resource.

element.name: code
element.description: read | vread | update | patch | delete | history-instance | history-type | create | search-type
element.definition: Coded identifier of the operation, supported by the system resource.

binding.name: TypeRestfulInteraction
binding.description: Operations supported by REST at the type or instance level.

element.name: documentation
element.definition: Guidance specific to the implementation of this operation, such as 'delete is a logical delete' or 'updates are only allowed with version id' or 'creates permitted from pre-authorized certificates only'.

element.name: name
element.description: Name by which the operation/query is invoked
element.definition: The name of the operation or query. For an operation, this is the name prefixed with $ and used in the URL. For a query, this is the name used in the _query parameter when the query is called.
element.comment: The name here SHOULD be the same as the name in the definition, unless there is a name clash and the name cannot be used. The name does not include the "$" portion that is always included in the URL.

element.name: definition
element.definition: Where the formal definition can be found. If a server references the base definition of an Operation (i.e. from the specification itself such as ```http://hl7.org/fhir/OperationDefinition/ValueSet-expand```), that means it supports the full capabilities of the operation - e.g. both GET and POST invocation. If it only supports a subset, it must define its own custom [OperationDefinition](operationdefinition.html#) with a 'base' of the original OperationDefinition. The custom definition would describe the specific subset of functionality supported.
element.comment: This can be used to build an HTML form to invoke the operation, for instance.

element.name: documentation
element.definition: Documentation that describes anything special about the operation behavior, possibly detailing different behavior for system, type and instance-level invocation of the operation.

element.name: name
element.definition: The name of the search parameter used in the interface.
element.comment: Parameter names cannot overlap with standard parameter names, and standard parameters cannot be redefined.

element.name: definition
element.definition: An absolute URI that is a formal reference to where this parameter was first defined, so that a client can be confident of the meaning of the search parameter (a reference to [SearchParameter.url](searchparameter-definitions.html#SearchParameter.url)). This element SHALL be populated if the search parameter refers to a SearchParameter defined by the FHIR core specification or externally defined IGs.
element.comment: This SHOULD be present, and matches refers to a SearchParameter by its canonical URL. If systems wish to document their support for modifiers, comparators, target resource types, and chained parameters, they should do using a search parameter resource. This element SHALL be populated if the search parameter refers to a SearchParameter defined by the FHIR core specification or externally defined IGs.

element.name: type
element.description: number | date | string | token | reference | composite | quantity | uri | special
element.definition: The type of value a search parameter refers to, and how the content is interpreted.
element.comment: While this can be looked up from the definition, it is included here as a convenience for systems that autogenerate a query interface based on the server capability statement. It SHALL be the same as the type in the search parameter definition.

binding.name: SearchParamType
binding.description: Data types allowed to be used for search parameters.

element.name: documentation
element.definition: This allows documentation of any distinct behaviors about how the search parameter is used. For example, text matching algorithms.

element.name: cors
element.definition: Server adds CORS headers when responding to requests - this enables Javascript applications to use the server.
element.comment: The easiest CORS headers to add are Access-Control-Allow-Origin: * & Access-Control-Request-Method: GET, POST, PUT, DELETE. All servers SHOULD support CORS.

element.name: service
element.description: OAuth | SMART-on-FHIR | NTLM | Basic | Kerberos | Certificates
element.definition: Types of security services that are supported/required by the system.

binding.name: RestfulSecurityService
binding.description: Types of security services used with FHIR.

element.name: description
element.description: General description of how security works
element.definition: General description of how security works.

element.name: name
element.description: A name the software is known by
element.definition: Name the software is known by.

element.name: version
element.definition: The version identifier for the software covered by this statement.
element.comment: If possible, a version should be specified, as statements are likely to be different for different versions of software.

element.name: releaseDate
element.definition: Date this version of the software was released.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: Business identifiers assigned to this care plan by the performer or other systems which remain constant as the resource is updated and propagates from server to server.
element.comment: This is a business identifier, not a resource identifier (see [discussion](resource.html#identifiers)). It is best practice for the identifier to only appear on a single resource instance, however business practices may occasionally dictate that multiple resource instances with the same identifier can exist - possibly even with different resource types. For example, multiple Patient and a Person resource instance might share the same social insurance number.

element.name: instantiatesCanonical
element.definition: The URL pointing to a FHIR-defined protocol, guideline, questionnaire or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this CarePlan.

element.name: instantiatesUri
element.definition: The URL pointing to an externally maintained protocol, guideline, questionnaire or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this CarePlan.
element.comment: This might be an HTML page, PDF, etc. or could just be a non-resolvable URI identifier.

element.name: basedOn
element.definition: A care plan that is fulfilled in whole or in part by this care plan.

element.name: replaces
element.definition: Completed or terminated care plan whose function is taken by this new care plan.
element.comment: The replacement could be because the initial care plan was immediately rejected (due to an issue) or because the previous care plan was completed, but the need for the action described by the care plan remains ongoing.

element.name: partOf
element.definition: A larger care plan of which this particular care plan is a component or step.
element.comment: Each care plan is an independent request, such that having a care plan be part of another care plan can cause issues with cascading statuses. As such, this element is still being discussed.

element.name: status
element.description: draft | active | on-hold | revoked | completed | entered-in-error | unknown
element.definition: Indicates whether the plan is currently being acted upon, represents future intentions or is now a historical record.
element.comment:
The unknown code is not to be used to convey other statuses. The unknown code should be used when one of the statuses applies, but the authoring system doesn't know the current state of the care plan.
This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains the code entered-in-error that marks the plan as not currently valid.

binding.name: CarePlanStatus
binding.description: Indicates whether the plan is currently being acted upon, represents future intentions or is now a historical record.

element.name: intent
element.definition: Indicates the level of authority/intentionality associated with the care plan and where the care plan fits into the workflow chain.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the intent alters when and how the resource is actually applicable.

binding.name: CarePlanIntent
binding.description: Codes indicating the degree of authority/intentionality associated with a care plan.

element.name: category
element.definition: Identifies what "kind" of plan this is to support differentiation between multiple co-existing plans; e.g. "Home health", "psychiatric", "asthma", "disease management", "wellness plan", etc.
element.comment: There may be multiple axes of categorization and one plan may serve multiple purposes. In some cases, this may be redundant with references to CarePlan.concern.

binding.name: CarePlanCategory
binding.description: Identifies what "kind" of plan this is to support differentiation between multiple co-existing plans; e.g. "Home health", "psychiatric", "asthma", "disease management", etc.

element.name: title
element.description: Human-friendly name for the care plan
element.definition: Human-friendly name for the care plan.

element.name: description
element.definition: A description of the scope and nature of the plan.

element.name: subject
element.description: Who the care plan is for
element.definition: Identifies the patient or group whose intended care is described by the plan.

element.name: encounter
element.definition: The Encounter during which this CarePlan was created or to which the creation of this record is tightly associated.
element.comment: This will typically be the encounter the event occurred within, but some activities may be initiated prior to or after the official completion of an encounter but still be tied to the context of the encounter. CarePlan activities conducted as a result of the care plan may well occur as part of other encounters.

element.name: period
element.definition: Indicates when the plan did (or is intended to) come into effect and end.
element.comment: Any activities scheduled as part of the plan should be constrained to the specified period regardless of whether the activities are planned within a single encounter/episode or across multiple encounters/episodes (e.g. the longitudinal management of a chronic condition).

element.name: created
element.definition: Represents when this particular CarePlan record was created in the system, which is often a system-generated date.

element.name: author
element.description: Who is the designated responsible party
element.definition: When populated, the author is responsible for the care plan. The care plan is attributed to the author.
element.comment: The author may also be a contributor. For example, an organization can be an author, but not listed as a contributor.

element.name: contributor
element.description: Who provided the content of the care plan
element.definition: Identifies the individual(s) or organization who provided the contents of the care plan.
element.comment: Collaborative care plans may have multiple contributors.

element.name: careTeam
element.definition: Identifies all people and organizations who are expected to be involved in the care envisioned by this plan.

element.name: addresses
element.definition: Identifies the conditions/problems/concerns/diagnoses/etc. whose management and/or mitigation are handled by this plan.
element.comment: When the diagnosis is related to an allergy or intolerance, the Condition and AllergyIntolerance resources can both be used. However, to be actionable for decision support, using Condition alone is not sufficient as the allergy or intolerance condition needs to be represented as an AllergyIntolerance.

element.name: supportingInfo
element.description: Information considered as part of plan
element.definition: Identifies portions of the patient's record that specifically influenced the formation of the plan. These might include comorbidities, recent procedures, limitations, recent assessments, etc.
element.comment: Use "concern" to identify specific conditions addressed by the care plan.

element.name: goal
element.definition: Describes the intended objective(s) of carrying out the care plan.
element.comment: Goal can be achieving a particular change or merely maintaining a current state or even slowing a decline.

element.name: activity
element.description: Action to occur as part of plan
element.definition: Identifies a planned action to occur as part of the plan. For example, a medication to be used, lab tests to perform, self-monitoring, education, etc.

constraint.name: cpl-3
constraint.message: Provide a reference or detail, not both

element.name: note
element.definition: General notes about the care plan not covered elsewhere.

element.name: outcomeCodeableConcept
element.definition: Identifies the outcome at the point when the status of the activity is assessed. For example, the outcome of an education activity could be patient understands (or not).
element.comment: Note that this should not duplicate the activity status (e.g. completed or in progress).

binding.name: CarePlanActivityOutcome
binding.description: Identifies the results of the activity.

element.name: outcomeReference
element.definition: Details of the outcome or action resulting from the activity. The reference to an "event" resource, such as Procedure or Encounter or Observation, is the result/outcome of the activity itself. The activity can be conveyed using CarePlan.activity.detail OR using the CarePlan.activity.reference (a reference to a request resource).
element.comment: The activity outcome is independent of the outcome of the related goal(s). For example, if the goal is to achieve a target body weight of 150 lbs and an activity is defined to diet, then the activity outcome could be calories consumed whereas the goal outcome is an observation for the actual body weight measured.

element.name: progress
element.definition: Notes about the adherence/status/progress of the activity.
element.comment: This element should NOT be used to describe the activity to be performed - that occurs either within the resource pointed to by activity.detail.reference or in activity.detail.description.

element.name: reference
element.description: Activity details defined in specific resource
element.definition: The details of the proposed activity represented in a specific resource.
element.comment: Standard extension exists ([resource-pertainsToGoal](extension-resource-pertainstogoal.html)) that allows goals to be referenced from any of the referenced resources in CarePlan.activity.reference. The goal should be visible when the resource referenced by CarePlan.activity.reference is viewed independently from the CarePlan. Requests that are pointed to by a CarePlan using this element should *not* point to this CarePlan using the "basedOn" element. i.e. Requests that are part of a CarePlan are not "based on" the CarePlan.

element.name: detail
element.definition: A simple summary of a planned activity suitable for a general care plan system (e.g. form driven) that doesn't know about specific resources such as procedure etc.

element.name: kind
element.description: Appointment | CommunicationRequest | DeviceRequest | MedicationRequest | NutritionOrder | Task | ServiceRequest | VisionPrescription
element.definition: A description of the kind of resource the in-line definition of a care plan activity is representing. The CarePlan.activity.detail is an in-line definition when a resource is not referenced using CarePlan.activity.reference. For example, a MedicationRequest, a ServiceRequest, or a CommunicationRequest.

binding.name: CarePlanActivityKind
binding.description: Resource types defined as part of FHIR that can be represented as in-line definitions of a care plan activity.

element.name: instantiatesCanonical
element.definition: The URL pointing to a FHIR-defined protocol, guideline, questionnaire or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this CarePlan activity.

element.name: instantiatesUri
element.definition: The URL pointing to an externally maintained protocol, guideline, questionnaire or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this CarePlan activity.
element.comment: This might be an HTML page, PDF, etc. or could just be a non-resolvable URI identifier.

element.name: code
element.definition: Detailed description of the type of planned activity; e.g. what lab test, what procedure, what kind of encounter.
element.comment: Tends to be less relevant for activities involving particular products. Codes should not convey negation - use "prohibited" instead.

binding.name: CarePlanActivityType
binding.description: Detailed description of the type of activity; e.g. What lab test, what procedure, what kind of encounter.

element.name: reasonCode
element.description: Why activity should be done or why activity was prohibited
element.definition: Provides the rationale that drove the inclusion of this particular activity as part of the plan or the reason why the activity was prohibited.
element.comment: This could be a diagnosis code. If a full condition record exists or additional detail is needed, use reasonCondition instead.

binding.name: CarePlanActivityReason
binding.description: Identifies why a care plan activity is needed. Can include any health condition codes as well as such concepts as "general wellness", prophylaxis, surgical preparation, etc.

element.name: reasonReference
element.definition: Indicates another resource, such as the health condition(s), whose existence justifies this request and drove the inclusion of this particular activity as part of the plan.
element.comment: Conditions can be identified at the activity level that are not identified as reasons for the overall plan.

element.name: goal
element.definition: Internal reference that identifies the goals that this activity is intended to contribute towards meeting.

element.name: status
element.description: not-started | scheduled | in-progress | on-hold | completed | cancelled | stopped | unknown | entered-in-error
element.definition: Identifies what progress is being made for the specific activity.
element.comment: Some aspects of status can be inferred based on the resources linked in actionTaken. Note that "status" is only as current as the plan was most recently updated. The unknown code is not to be used to convey other statuses. The unknown code should be used when one of the statuses applies, but the authoring system doesn't know the current state of the activity.

binding.name: CarePlanActivityStatus
binding.description: Codes that reflect the current state of a care plan activity within its overall life cycle.

element.name: statusReason
element.definition: Provides reason why the activity isn't yet started, is on hold, was cancelled, etc.
element.comment: Will generally not be present if status is "complete". Be sure to prompt to update this (or at least remove the existing value) if the status is changed.

element.name: doNotPerform
element.description: If true, activity is prohibiting action
element.definition: If true, indicates that the described activity is one that must NOT be engaged in when following the plan. If false, or missing, indicates that the described activity is one that should be engaged in when following the plan.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because it marks an activity as an activity that is not to be performed.

element.name: scheduled
element.definition: The period, timing or frequency upon which the described activity is to occur.

element.name: location
element.definition: Identifies the facility where the activity will occur; e.g. home, hospital, specific clinic, etc.
element.comment: May reference a specific clinical location or may identify a type of location.

element.name: performer
element.definition: Identifies who's expected to be involved in the activity.
element.comment: A performer MAY also be a participant in the care plan.

element.name: product
element.definition: Identifies the food, drug or other product to be consumed or supplied in the activity.

binding.name: CarePlanProduct
binding.description: A product supplied or administered as part of a care plan activity.

element.name: dailyAmount
element.definition: Identifies the quantity expected to be consumed in a given day.

element.name: quantity
element.definition: Identifies the quantity expected to be supplied, administered or consumed by the subject.

element.name: description
element.description: Extra info describing activity to perform
element.definition: This provides a textual description of constraints on the intended activity occurrence, including relation to other activities. It may also include objectives, pre-conditions and end-conditions. Finally, it may convey specifics about the activity such as body site, method, route, etc.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: Business identifiers assigned to this care team by the performer or other systems which remain constant as the resource is updated and propagates from server to server.
element.comment: This is a business identifier, not a resource identifier (see [discussion](resource.html#identifiers)). It is best practice for the identifier to only appear on a single resource instance, however business practices may occasionally dictate that multiple resource instances with the same identifier can exist - possibly even with different resource types. For example, multiple Patient and a Person resource instance might share the same social insurance number.

element.name: status
element.definition: Indicates the current state of the care team.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains the code entered-in-error that marks the care team as not currently valid.

binding.name: CareTeamStatus
binding.description: Indicates the status of the care team.

element.name: category
element.definition: Identifies what kind of team. This is to support differentiation between multiple co-existing teams, such as care plan team, episode of care team, longitudinal care team.
element.comment: There may be multiple axis of categorization and one team may serve multiple purposes.

binding.name: CareTeamCategory
binding.description: Indicates the type of care team.

element.name: name
element.description: Name of the team, such as crisis assessment team
element.definition: A label for human use intended to distinguish like teams. E.g. the "red" vs. "green" trauma teams.
element.comment: The meaning/purpose of the team is conveyed in CareTeam.category. This element may also convey semantics of the team (e.g. "Red trauma team"), but its primary purpose is to distinguish between identical teams in a human-friendly way. ("Team 18735" isn't as friendly.).

element.name: subject
element.definition: Identifies the patient or group whose intended care is handled by the team.

element.name: encounter
element.definition: The Encounter during which this CareTeam was created or to which the creation of this record is tightly associated.
element.comment: This will typically be the encounter the event occurred within, but some activities may be initiated prior to or after the official completion of an encounter but still be tied to the context of the encounter.

element.name: period
element.definition: Indicates when the team did (or is intended to) come into effect and end.

element.name: participant
element.definition: Identifies all people and organizations who are expected to be involved in the care team.

constraint.name: ctm-1
constraint.message: CareTeam.participant.onBehalfOf can only be populated when CareTeam.participant.member is a Practitioner

element.name: reasonCode
element.definition: Describes why the care team exists.

binding.name: CareTeamReason
binding.description: Indicates the reason for the care team.

element.name: reasonReference
element.definition: Condition(s) that this care team addresses.

element.name: managingOrganization
element.description: Organization responsible for the care team
element.definition: The organization responsible for the care team.

element.name: telecom
element.description: A contact detail for the care team (that applies to all members)
element.definition: A central contact detail for the care team (that applies to all members).
element.comment: The ContactPoint.use code of home is not appropriate to use. These contacts are not the contact details of individual care team members.

element.name: note
element.definition: Comments made about the CareTeam.

element.name: role
element.definition: Indicates specific responsibility of an individual within the care team, such as "Primary care physician", "Trained social worker counselor", "Caregiver", etc.
element.comment: Roles may sometimes be inferred by type of Practitioner. These are relationships that hold only within the context of the care team. General relationships should be handled as properties of the Patient resource directly.

binding.name: CareTeamParticipantRole
binding.description: Indicates specific responsibility of an individual within the care team, such as "Primary physician", "Team coordinator", "Caregiver", etc.

element.name: member
element.definition: The specific person or organization who is participating/expected to participate in the care team.
element.comment:
Patient only needs to be listed if they have a role other than "subject of care".
Member is optional because some participants may be known only by their role, particularly in draft plans.

element.name: onBehalfOf
element.definition: The organization of the practitioner.

element.name: period
element.definition: Indicates when the specific member or organization did (or is intended to) come into effect and end.

element.name: identifier
element.description: Unique identifier of the catalog item
element.definition: Used in supporting different identifiers for the same product, e.g. manufacturer code and retailer code.

element.name: type
element.description: The type of item - medication, device, service, protocol or other
element.definition: The type of item - medication, device, service, protocol or other.

element.name: orderable
element.description: Whether the entry represents an orderable item
element.definition: Whether the entry represents an orderable item.

element.name: referencedItem
element.description: The item that is being defined
element.definition: The item in a catalog or definition.

element.name: additionalIdentifier
element.description: Any additional identifier(s) for the catalog item, in the same granularity or concept
element.definition: Used in supporting related concepts, e.g. NDC to RxNorm.

element.name: classification
element.description: Classification (category or class) of the item entry
element.definition: Classes of devices, or ATC for medication.

element.name: status
element.definition: Used to support catalog exchange even for unsupported products, e.g. getting list of medications even if not prescribable.

binding.name: PublicationStatus
binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.name: validityPeriod
element.description: The time period in which this catalog entry is expected to be active
element.definition: The time period in which this catalog entry is expected to be active.

element.name: validTo
element.description: The date until which this catalog entry is expected to be active
element.definition: The date until which this catalog entry is expected to be active.

element.name: lastUpdated
element.description: When was this catalog last updated
element.definition: Typically date of issue is different from the beginning of the validity. This can be used to see when an item was last updated.
element.comment: Perhaps not needed - if we use fhir resource metadata.

element.name: additionalCharacteristic
element.description: Additional characteristics of the catalog entry
element.definition: Used for examplefor Out of Formulary, or any specifics.

element.name: additionalClassification
element.description: Additional classification of the catalog entry
element.definition: User for example for ATC classification, or.

element.name: relatedEntry
element.description: An item that this catalog entry is related to
element.definition: Used for example, to point to a substance, or to a device used to administer a medication.

element.name: relationtype
element.definition: The type of relation to the related item: child, parent, packageContent, containerPackage, usedIn, uses, requires, etc.

binding.name: CatalogEntryRelationType
binding.description: The type of relations between entries.

element.name: item
element.description: The reference to the related item
element.definition: The reference to the related item.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: Identifiers assigned to this event performer or other systems.

element.name: definitionUri
element.description: Defining information about the code of this charge item
element.definition: References the (external) source of pricing information, rules of application for the code this ChargeItem uses.

element.name: definitionCanonical
element.description: Resource defining the code of this ChargeItem
element.definition: References the source of pricing information, rules of application for the code this ChargeItem uses.

element.name: status
element.description: planned | billable | not-billable | aborted | billed | entered-in-error | unknown
element.definition: The current state of the ChargeItem.
element.comment:
Unknown does not represent "other" - one of the defined statuses must apply. Unknown is used when the authoring system is not sure what the current status is.
This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains the code entered-in-error that marks the charge item as not currently valid.

binding.name: ChargeItemStatus
binding.description: Codes identifying the lifecycle stage of a ChargeItem.

element.name: partOf
element.definition: ChargeItems can be grouped to larger ChargeItems covering the whole set.

element.name: code
element.description: A code that identifies the charge, like a billing code
element.definition: A code that identifies the charge, like a billing code.

binding.name: ChargeItemCode
binding.description: Example set of codes that can be used for billing purposes.

element.name: subject
element.definition: The individual or set of individuals the action is being or was performed on.

element.name: context
element.definition: The encounter or episode of care that establishes the context for this event.

element.name: occurrence
element.description: When the charged service was applied
element.definition: Date/time(s) or duration when the charged service was applied.
element.comment: The list of types may be constrained as appropriate for the type of charge item.

element.name: performer
element.definition: Indicates who or what performed or participated in the charged service.

element.name: performingOrganization
element.definition: The organization requesting the service.
element.comment: Practitioners and Devices can be associated with multiple organizations. It has to be made clear, on behalf of which Organization the services have been rendered.

element.name: requestingOrganization
element.definition: The organization performing the service.
element.comment: The rendered Service might not be associated with a Request. This property indicates which Organization requested the services to be rendered. (In many cases, this may just be the Department associated with the Encounter.location).

element.name: costCenter
element.description: Organization that has ownership of the (potential, future) revenue
element.definition: The financial cost center permits the tracking of charge attribution.
element.comment: The costCenter could either be given as a reference to an Organization(Role) resource or as the identifier of the cost center determined by Reference.identifier.value and Reference.identifier.system, depending on use case requirements.

element.name: quantity
element.description: Quantity of which the charge item has been serviced
element.definition: Quantity of which the charge item has been serviced.
element.comment: In many cases this may just be a value, if the underlying units are implicit in the definition of the charge item code.

element.name: bodysite
element.definition: The anatomical location where the related service has been applied.
element.comment: Only used if not implicit in code found in Condition.code. If the use case requires attributes from the BodySite resource (e.g. to identify and track separately) then use the standard extension [bodySite](extension-bodysite.html). May be a summary code, or a reference to a very precise definition of the location, or both.

binding.name: BodySite
binding.description: Codes describing anatomical locations. May include laterality.

element.name: factorOverride
element.definition: Factor overriding the factor determined by the rules associated with the code.
element.comment: There is no reason to carry the factor in the instance of a ChargeItem unless special circumstances require a manual override. The factors are usually defined by a set of rules in a back catalogue of the billing codes (see ChargeItem.definition). Derived profiles may require a ChargeItem.overrideReason to be provided if either factor or price are manually overridden.

element.name: priceOverride
element.definition: Total price of the charge overriding the list price associated with the code.
element.comment: There is no reason to carry the price in the instance of a ChargeItem unless circumstances require a manual override. The list prices or are usually defined in a back catalogue of the billing codes (see ChargeItem.definition). Derived profiles may require a ChargeItem.overrideReason to be provided if either factor or price are manually overridden.

element.name: overrideReason
element.description: Reason for overriding the list price/factor
element.definition: If the list price or the rule-based factor associated with the code is overridden, this attribute can capture a text to indicate the reason for this action.
element.comment: Derived Profiles may choose to add invariants requiring this field to be populated if either priceOverride or factorOverride have been filled.

element.name: enterer
element.definition: The device, practitioner, etc. who entered the charge item.
element.comment: The enterer is also the person considered responsible for factor/price overrides if applicable.

element.name: enteredDate
element.description: Date the charge item was entered
element.definition: Date the charge item was entered.
element.comment: The actual date when the service associated with the charge has been rendered is captured in occurrence[x].

element.name: reason
element.description: Why was the charged service rendered?
element.definition: Describes why the event occurred in coded or textual form.
element.comment: If the application of the charge item requires a reason to be given, it can be captured here. Textual reasons can be captured using reasonCode.text.

binding.name: ChargeItemReason
binding.description: Example binding for reason.

element.name: service
element.description: Which rendered service is being charged?
element.definition: Indicated the rendered service that caused this charge.

element.name: product
element.definition: Identifies the device, food, drug or other product being charged either by type code or reference to an instance.

binding.name: ChargeItemProduct
binding.description: Example binding for product type.

element.name: account
element.definition: Account into which this ChargeItems belongs.
element.comment: Systems posting the ChargeItems might not always be able to determine, which accounts the Items need to be places into. It is up to the postprocessing Financial System to apply internal rules to decide based on the Encounter/EpisodeOfCare/Patient/Coverage context and the type of ChargeItem, which Account is appropriate.
