If one or more discriminators are provided, the value of the child elements in the instance data SHALL completely distinguish which slice the element in the resource matches based on the allowed values for those elements in each of the slices.
element.comment: If there is no discriminator, the content is hard to process, so this should be avoided.

element.name: description
element.description: Text description of how slicing works (or not)
element.definition: A human-readable text description of how the slicing works. If there is no discriminator, this is required to be present to provide whatever information is possible about how the slices can be differentiated.
element.comment: If it's really not possible to differentiate them, the design should be re-evaluated to make the content usable.

element.name: ordered
element.description: If elements must be in same order as slices
element.definition: If the matching elements have to occur in the same order as defined in the profile.
element.comment: Order should only be required when it is a pressing concern for presentation. Profile authors should consider making the order a feature of the rules about the narrative, not the rules about the data - requiring ordered data makes the profile much less re-usable.

element.name: rules
element.definition: Whether additional slices are allowed or not. When the slices are ordered, profile authors can also say that additional slices are only allowed at the end.
element.comment: Allowing additional elements makes for a much for flexible template - it's open for use in wider contexts, but also means that the content of the resource is not closed, and applications have to decide how to handle content not described by the profile.

binding.name: SlicingRules
binding.description: How slices are interpreted when evaluating an instance.

element.name: type
element.definition: How the element value is interpreted when discrimination is evaluated.

binding.name: DiscriminatorType
binding.description: How an element value is interpreted when discrimination is evaluated.

element.name: path
element.definition: A FHIRPath expression, using [the simple subset of FHIRPath](fhirpath.html#simple), that is used to identify the element on which discrimination is based.
element.comment: The only FHIRPath functions that are allowed are as(type), resolve(), and extension(url).

element.name: code
element.description: Data type or Resource (reference to definition)
element.definition: URL of Data type or Resource that is a(or the) type used for this element. References are URLs that are relative to http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition e.g. "string" is a reference to http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/string. Absolute URLs are only allowed in logical models.
element.comment: If the element is a reference to another resource, this element contains "Reference", and the targetProfile element defines what resources can be referenced. The targetProfile may be a reference to the general definition of a resource (e.g. http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/Patient).

binding.name: FHIRDefinedTypeExt
binding.description: Either a resource or a data type, including logical model types.

element.name: profile
element.description: Profiles (StructureDefinition or IG) - one must apply
element.definition: Identifies a profile structure or implementation Guide that applies to the datatype this element refers to. If any profiles are specified, then the content must conform to at least one of them. The URL can be a local reference - to a contained StructureDefinition, or a reference to another StructureDefinition or Implementation Guide by a canonical URL. When an implementation guide is specified, the type SHALL conform to at least one profile defined in the implementation guide.
element.comment: It is possible to profile backbone element (e.g. part of a resource), using the [profile-element](extension-elementdefinition-profile-element.html) extension.

element.name: targetProfile
element.description: Profile (StructureDefinition or IG) on the Reference/canonical target - one must apply
element.definition: Used when the type is "Reference" or "canonical", and identifies a profile structure or implementation Guide that applies to the target of the reference this element refers to. If any profiles are specified, then the content must conform to at least one of them. The URL can be a local reference - to a contained StructureDefinition, or a reference to another StructureDefinition or Implementation Guide by a canonical URL. When an implementation guide is specified, the target resource SHALL conform to at least one profile defined in the implementation guide.

element.name: aggregation
element.definition: If the type is a reference to another resource, how the resource is or can be aggregated - is it a contained resource, or a reference, and if the context is a bundle, is it included in the bundle.
element.comment: See [Aggregation Rules](elementdefinition.html#aggregation) for further clarification.

binding.name: AggregationMode
binding.description: How resource references can be aggregated.

element.name: versioning
element.definition: Whether this reference needs to be version specific or version independent, or whether either can be used.
element.comment: The base specification never makes a rule as to which form is allowed, but implementation guides may do this. See [Aggregation Rules](elementdefinition.html#aggregation) for further clarification.

binding.name: ReferenceVersionRules
binding.description: Whether a reference needs to be version specific or version independent, or whether either can be used.

element.name: identifier
element.description: Identifier(s) by which this encounter is known
element.definition: Identifier(s) by which this encounter is known.

element.name: status
element.description: planned | arrived | triaged | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled +
element.definition: planned | arrived | triaged | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled +.
element.comment: Note that internal business rules will determine the appropriate transitions that may occur between statuses (and also classes).

binding.name: EncounterStatus
binding.description: Current state of the encounter.

element.name: statusHistory
element.definition: The status history permits the encounter resource to contain the status history without needing to read through the historical versions of the resource, or even have the server store them.
element.comment: The current status is always found in the current version of the resource, not the status history.

element.name: class
element.definition: Concepts representing classification of patient encounter such as ambulatory (outpatient), inpatient, emergency, home health or others due to local variations.

binding.name: EncounterClass
binding.description: Classification of the encounter.

element.name: classHistory
element.definition: The class history permits the tracking of the encounters transitions without needing to go through the resource history. This would be used for a case where an admission starts of as an emergency encounter, then transitions into an inpatient scenario. Doing this and not restarting a new encounter ensures that any lab/diagnostic results can more easily follow the patient and not require re-processing and not get lost or cancelled during a kind of discharge from emergency to inpatient.

element.name: type
element.definition: Specific type of encounter (e.g. e-mail consultation, surgical day-care, skilled nursing, rehabilitation).
element.comment: Since there are many ways to further classify encounters, this element is 0..*.

binding.name: EncounterType
binding.description: The type of encounter.

element.name: serviceType
element.definition: Broad categorization of the service that is to be provided (e.g. cardiology).

binding.name: EncounterServiceType
binding.description: Broad categorization of the service that is to be provided.

element.name: priority
element.description: Indicates the urgency of the encounter
element.definition: Indicates the urgency of the encounter.

binding.name: Priority
binding.description: Indicates the urgency of the encounter.

element.name: subject
element.description: The patient or group present at the encounter
element.definition: The patient or group present at the encounter.
element.comment: While the encounter is always about the patient, the patient might not actually be known in all contexts of use, and there may be a group of patients that could be anonymous (such as in a group therapy for Alcoholics Anonymous - where the recording of the encounter could be used for billing on the number of people/staff and not important to the context of the specific patients) or alternately in veterinary care a herd of sheep receiving treatment (where the animals are not individually tracked).

element.name: episodeOfCare
element.description: Episode(s) of care that this encounter should be recorded against
element.definition: Where a specific encounter should be classified as a part of a specific episode(s) of care this field should be used. This association can facilitate grouping of related encounters together for a specific purpose, such as government reporting, issue tracking, association via a common problem. The association is recorded on the encounter as these are typically created after the episode of care and grouped on entry rather than editing the episode of care to append another encounter to it (the episode of care could span years).

element.name: basedOn
element.description: The ServiceRequest that initiated this encounter
element.definition: The request this encounter satisfies (e.g. incoming referral or procedure request).

element.name: participant
element.description: List of participants involved in the encounter
element.definition: The list of people responsible for providing the service.

element.name: appointment
element.description: The appointment that scheduled this encounter
element.definition: The appointment that scheduled this encounter.

element.name: period
element.description: The start and end time of the encounter
element.definition: The start and end time of the encounter.
element.comment: If not (yet) known, the end of the Period may be omitted.

element.name: length
element.description: Quantity of time the encounter lasted (less time absent)
element.definition: Quantity of time the encounter lasted. This excludes the time during leaves of absence.
element.comment: May differ from the time the Encounter.period lasted because of leave of absence.

element.name: reasonCode
element.description: Coded reason the encounter takes place
element.definition: Reason the encounter takes place, expressed as a code. For admissions, this can be used for a coded admission diagnosis.
element.comment: For systems that need to know which was the primary diagnosis, these will be marked with the standard extension primaryDiagnosis (which is a sequence value rather than a flag, 1 = primary diagnosis).

binding.name: EncounterReason
binding.description: Reason why the encounter takes place.

element.name: reasonReference
element.definition: Reason the encounter takes place, expressed as a code. For admissions, this can be used for a coded admission diagnosis.
element.comment: For systems that need to know which was the primary diagnosis, these will be marked with the standard extension primaryDiagnosis (which is a sequence value rather than a flag, 1 = primary diagnosis).

element.name: diagnosis
element.description: The list of diagnosis relevant to this encounter
element.definition: The list of diagnosis relevant to this encounter.

element.name: account
element.description: The set of accounts that may be used for billing for this Encounter
element.definition: The set of accounts that may be used for billing for this Encounter.
element.comment: The billing system may choose to allocate billable items associated with the Encounter to different referenced Accounts based on internal business rules.

element.name: hospitalization
element.description: Details about the admission to a healthcare service
element.definition: Details about the admission to a healthcare service.
element.comment: An Encounter may cover more than just the inpatient stay. Contexts such as outpatients, community clinics, and aged care facilities are also included. The duration recorded in the period of this encounter covers the entire scope of this hospitalization record.

element.name: location
element.description: List of locations where the patient has been
element.definition: List of locations where the patient has been during this encounter.
element.comment: Virtual encounters can be recorded in the Encounter by specifying a location reference to a location of type "kind" such as "client's home" and an encounter.class = "virtual".

element.name: serviceProvider
element.description: The organization (facility) responsible for this encounter
element.definition: The organization that is primarily responsible for this Encounter's services. This MAY be the same as the organization on the Patient record, however it could be different, such as if the actor performing the services was from an external organization (which may be billed seperately) for an external consultation. Refer to the example bundle showing an abbreviated set of Encounters for a colonoscopy.

element.name: partOf
element.description: Another Encounter this encounter is part of
element.definition: Another Encounter of which this encounter is a part of (administratively or in time).
element.comment: This is also used for associating a child's encounter back to the mother's encounter. Refer to the Notes section in the Patient resource for further details.

element.name: class
element.definition: inpatient | outpatient | ambulatory | emergency +.

binding.name: EncounterClass
binding.description: Classification of the encounter.

element.name: period
element.description: The time that the episode was in the specified class
element.definition: The time that the episode was in the specified class.

element.name: condition
element.description: The diagnosis or procedure relevant to the encounter
element.definition: Reason the encounter takes place, as specified using information from another resource. For admissions, this is the admission diagnosis. The indication will typically be a Condition (with other resources referenced in the evidence.detail), or a Procedure.
element.comment: For systems that need to know which was the primary diagnosis, these will be marked with the standard extension primaryDiagnosis (which is a sequence value rather than a flag, 1 = primary diagnosis).

element.name: use
element.description: Role that this diagnosis has within the encounter (e.g. admission, billing, discharge )
element.definition: Role that this diagnosis has within the encounter (e.g. admission, billing, discharge ).

binding.name: DiagnosisRole
binding.description: The type of diagnosis this condition represents.

element.name: rank
element.description: Ranking of the diagnosis (for each role type)
element.definition: Ranking of the diagnosis (for each role type).

element.name: preAdmissionIdentifier
element.definition: Pre-admission identifier.

element.name: origin
element.description: The location/organization from which the patient came before admission
element.definition: The location/organization from which the patient came before admission.

element.name: admitSource
element.description: From where patient was admitted (physician referral, transfer)
element.definition: From where patient was admitted (physician referral, transfer).

binding.name: AdmitSource
binding.description: From where the patient was admitted.

element.name: reAdmission
element.description: The type of hospital re-admission that has occurred (if any). If the value is absent, then this is not identified as a readmission
element.definition: Whether this hospitalization is a readmission and why if known.

binding.name: ReAdmissionType
binding.description: The reason for re-admission of this hospitalization encounter.

element.name: dietPreference
element.description: Diet preferences reported by the patient
element.definition: Diet preferences reported by the patient.
element.comment: For example, a patient may request both a dairy-free and nut-free diet preference (not mutually exclusive).

binding.name: PatientDiet
binding.description: Medical, cultural or ethical food preferences to help with catering requirements.

element.name: specialCourtesy
element.definition: Special courtesies (VIP, board member).

binding.name: Courtesies
binding.description: Special courtesies.

element.name: specialArrangement
element.definition: Any special requests that have been made for this hospitalization encounter, such as the provision of specific equipment or other things.

binding.name: Arrangements
binding.description: Special arrangements.

element.name: destination
element.description: Location/organization to which the patient is discharged
element.definition: Location/organization to which the patient is discharged.

element.name: dischargeDisposition
element.description: Category or kind of location after discharge
element.definition: Category or kind of location after discharge.

binding.name: DischargeDisp
binding.description: Discharge Disposition.

element.name: location
element.definition: The location where the encounter takes place.

element.name: status
element.definition: The status of the participants' presence at the specified location during the period specified. If the participant is no longer at the location, then the period will have an end date/time.
element.comment: When the patient is no longer active at a location, then the period end date is entered, and the status may be changed to completed.

binding.name: EncounterLocationStatus
binding.description: The status of the location.

element.name: physicalType
element.description: The physical type of the location (usually the level in the location hierachy - bed room ward etc.)
element.definition: This will be used to specify the required levels (bed/ward/room/etc.) desired to be recorded to simplify either messaging or query.
element.comment:
This information is de-normalized from the Location resource to support the easier understanding of the encounter resource and processing in messaging or query.
There may be many levels in the hierachy, and this may only pic specific levels that are required for a specific usage scenario.

binding.name: PhysicalType
binding.description: Physical form of the location.

element.name: period
element.description: Time period during which the patient was present at the location
element.definition: Time period during which the patient was present at the location.

element.name: type
element.definition: Role of participant in encounter.
element.comment: The participant type indicates how an individual participates in an encounter. It includes non-practitioner participants, and for practitioners this is to describe the action type in the context of this encounter (e.g. Admitting Dr, Attending Dr, Translator, Consulting Dr). This is different to the practitioner roles which are functional roles, derived from terms of employment, education, licensing, etc.

binding.name: ParticipantType
binding.description: Role of participant in encounter.

element.name: period
element.description: Period of time during the encounter that the participant participated
element.definition: The period of time that the specified participant participated in the encounter. These can overlap or be sub-sets of the overall encounter's period.

element.name: individual
element.description: Persons involved in the encounter other than the patient
element.definition: Persons involved in the encounter other than the patient.

element.name: status
element.description: planned | arrived | triaged | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled +
element.definition: planned | arrived | triaged | in-progress | onleave | finished | cancelled +.

binding.name: EncounterStatus
binding.description: Current state of the encounter.

element.name: period
element.description: The time that the episode was in the specified status
element.definition: The time that the episode was in the specified status.

element.name: identifier
element.description: Identifies this endpoint across multiple systems
element.definition: Identifier for the organization that is used to identify the endpoint across multiple disparate systems.

element.name: status
element.description: active | suspended | error | off | entered-in-error | test
element.definition: active | suspended | error | off | test.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the endpoint as not currently valid.

binding.name: EndpointStatus
binding.description: The status of the endpoint.

element.name: connectionType
element.description: Protocol/Profile/Standard to be used with this endpoint connection
element.definition: A coded value that represents the technical details of the usage of this endpoint, such as what WSDLs should be used in what way. (e.g. XDS.b/DICOM/cds-hook).
element.comment: For additional connectivity details for the protocol, extensions will be used at this point, as in the XDS example.

element.name: name
element.description: A name that this endpoint can be identified by
element.definition: A friendly name that this endpoint can be referred to with.

element.name: managingOrganization
element.description: Organization that manages this endpoint (might not be the organization that exposes the endpoint)
element.definition: The organization that manages this endpoint (even if technically another organization is hosting this in the cloud, it is the organization associated with the data).
element.comment: This property is not typically used when searching for Endpoint resources for usage. The typical usage is via the reference from an applicable Organization/Location/Practitioner resource, which is where the context is provided. Multiple Locations may reference a single endpoint, and don't have to be within the same organization resource, but most likely within the same organizational hierarchy.

element.name: contact
element.definition: Contact details for a human to contact about the subscription. The primary use of this for system administrator troubleshooting.

element.name: period
element.description: Interval the endpoint is expected to be operational
element.definition: The interval during which the endpoint is expected to be operational.

element.name: payloadType
element.description: The type of content that may be used at this endpoint (e.g. XDS Discharge summaries)
element.definition: The payload type describes the acceptable content that can be communicated on the endpoint.
element.comment: The payloadFormat describes the serialization format of the data, where the payloadType indicates the specific document/schema that is being transferred; e.g. DischargeSummary or CarePlan.

element.name: payloadMimeType
element.description: Mimetype to send. If not specified, the content could be anything (including no payload, if the connectionType defined this)
element.definition: The mime type to send the payload in - e.g. application/fhir+xml, application/fhir+json. If the mime type is not specified, then the sender could send any content (including no content depending on the connectionType).
element.comment: Sending the payload has obvious security consequences. The server is responsible for ensuring that the content is appropriately secured.

binding.name: MimeType
binding.description: The mime type of an attachment. Any valid mime type is allowed.

element.name: address
element.description: The technical base address for connecting to this endpoint
element.definition: The uri that describes the actual end-point to connect to.
element.comment:
For rest-hook, and websocket, the end-point must be an http: or https: URL; for email, a mailto: url, for sms, a tel: url, and for message the endpoint can be in any form of url the server understands (usually, http: or mllp:). The URI is allowed to be relative; in which case, it is relative to the server end-point (since there may be more than one, clients should avoid using relative URIs)
This address will be to the service base, without any parameters, or sub-services or resources tacked on.
E.g. for a WADO-RS endpoint, the url should be "https://pacs.hospital.org/wado-rs"
and not "https://pacs.hospital.org/wado-rs/studies/1.2.250.1.59.40211.12345678.678910/series/1.2.250.1.59.40211.789001276.14556172.67789/instances/...".

element.name: header
element.description: Usage depends on the channel type
element.definition: Additional headers / information to send as part of the notification.
element.comment: Exactly what these mean depends on the channel type. The can convey additional information to the recipient and/or meet security requirements.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: The Response business identifier.

element.name: status
element.definition: The status of the resource instance.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the request as not currently valid.

binding.name: EnrollmentRequestStatus
binding.description: A code specifying the state of the resource instance.

element.name: created
element.definition: The date when this resource was created.

element.name: insurer
element.definition: The Insurer who is target of the request.

element.name: provider
element.definition: The practitioner who is responsible for the services rendered to the patient.

element.name: candidate
element.definition: Patient Resource.

element.name: coverage
element.definition: Reference to the program or plan identification, underwriter or payor.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: The Response business identifier.

element.name: status
element.definition: The status of the resource instance.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the response as not currently valid.

binding.name: EnrollmentResponseStatus
binding.description: A code specifying the state of the resource instance.

element.name: request
element.definition: Original request resource reference.

element.name: outcome
element.definition: Processing status: error, complete.

binding.name: RemittanceOutcome
binding.description: The outcome of the processing.

element.name: disposition
element.definition: A description of the status of the adjudication.

element.name: created
element.definition: The date when the enclosed suite of services were performed or completed.

element.name: organization
element.definition: The Insurer who produced this adjudicated response.

element.name: requestProvider
element.definition: The practitioner who is responsible for the services rendered to the patient.

element.name: identifier
element.description: Business Identifier(s) relevant for this EpisodeOfCare
element.definition: The EpisodeOfCare may be known by different identifiers for different contexts of use, such as when an external agency is tracking the Episode for funding purposes.

element.name: status
element.description: planned | waitlist | active | onhold | finished | cancelled | entered-in-error
element.definition: planned | waitlist | active | onhold | finished | cancelled.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the episode as not currently valid.

binding.name: EpisodeOfCareStatus
binding.description: The status of the episode of care.

element.name: statusHistory
element.description: Past list of status codes (the current status may be included to cover the start date of the status)
element.definition: The history of statuses that the EpisodeOfCare has been through (without requiring processing the history of the resource).

element.name: type
element.description: Type/class - e.g. specialist referral, disease management
element.definition: A classification of the type of episode of care; e.g. specialist referral, disease management, type of funded care.
element.comment: The type can be very important in processing as this could be used in determining if the EpisodeOfCare is relevant to specific government reporting, or other types of classifications.

binding.name: EpisodeOfCareType
binding.description: The type of the episode of care.

element.name: diagnosis
element.description: The list of diagnosis relevant to this episode of care
element.definition: The list of diagnosis relevant to this episode of care.

element.name: patient
element.description: The patient who is the focus of this episode of care
element.definition: The patient who is the focus of this episode of care.

element.name: managingOrganization
element.definition: The organization that has assumed the specific responsibilities for the specified duration.

element.name: period
element.definition: The interval during which the managing organization assumes the defined responsibility.

element.name: referralRequest
element.definition: Referral Request(s) that are fulfilled by this EpisodeOfCare, incoming referrals.

element.name: careManager
element.description: Care manager/care coordinator for the patient
element.definition: The practitioner that is the care manager/care coordinator for this patient.

element.name: team
element.description: Other practitioners facilitating this episode of care
element.definition: The list of practitioners that may be facilitating this episode of care for specific purposes.

element.name: account
element.description: The set of accounts that may be used for billing for this EpisodeOfCare
element.definition: The set of accounts that may be used for billing for this EpisodeOfCare.
element.comment: The billing system may choose to allocate billable items associated with the EpisodeOfCare to different referenced Accounts based on internal business rules.

element.name: condition
element.description: Conditions/problems/diagnoses this episode of care is for
element.definition: A list of conditions/problems/diagnoses that this episode of care is intended to be providing care for.

element.name: role
element.description: Role that this diagnosis has within the episode of care (e.g. admission, billing, discharge )
element.definition: Role that this diagnosis has within the episode of care (e.g. admission, billing, discharge ).

binding.name: DiagnosisRole
binding.description: The type of diagnosis this condition represents.

element.name: rank
element.description: Ranking of the diagnosis (for each role type)
element.definition: Ranking of the diagnosis (for each role type).

element.name: status
element.description: planned | waitlist | active | onhold | finished | cancelled | entered-in-error
element.definition: planned | waitlist | active | onhold | finished | cancelled.

binding.name: EpisodeOfCareStatus
binding.description: The status of the episode of care.

element.name: period
element.description: Duration the EpisodeOfCare was in the specified status
element.definition: The period during this EpisodeOfCare that the specific status applied.

element.name: url
element.description: Canonical identifier for this event definition, represented as a URI (globally unique)
element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this event definition when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which at which an authoritative instance of this event definition is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the event definition is stored on different servers.
element.comment:
Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid: but real http: addresses are preferred. Multiple instances may share the same URL if they have a distinct version.
The determination of when to create a new version of a resource (same url, new version) vs. defining a new artifact is up to the author. Considerations for making this decision are found in [Technical and Business Versions](resource.html#versions).
In some cases, the resource can no longer be found at the stated url, but the url itself cannot change. Implementations can use the [meta.source](resource.html#meta) element to indicate where the current master source of the resource can be found.

element.name: identifier
element.description: Additional identifier for the event definition
element.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this event definition when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
element.comment: Typically, this is used for identifiers that can go in an HL7 V3 II (instance identifier) data type, and can then identify this event definition outside of FHIR, where it is not possible to use the logical URI.

element.name: version
element.description: Business version of the event definition
element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the event definition when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the event definition author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence.
element.comment: There may be different event definition instances that have the same identifier but different versions. The version can be appended to the url in a reference to allow a reference to a particular business version of the event definition with the format [url]|[version].

element.name: name
element.description: Name for this event definition (computer friendly)
element.definition: A natural language name identifying the event definition. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alphanumeric type name to ensure that it is machine-processing friendly.

element.name: title
element.description: Name for this event definition (human friendly)
element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the event definition.
element.comment: This name does not need to be machine-processing friendly and may contain punctuation, white-space, etc.

element.name: subtitle
element.description: Subordinate title of the event definition
element.definition: An explanatory or alternate title for the event definition giving additional information about its content.

element.name: status
element.definition: The status of this event definition. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content.
element.comment: Allows filtering of event definitions that are appropriate for use versus not.

binding.name: PublicationStatus
binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.name: experimental
element.description: For testing purposes, not real usage
element.definition: A Boolean value to indicate that this event definition is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing) and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.comment: Allows filtering of event definitions that are appropriate for use versus not.

element.name: subject
element.description: Type of individual the event definition is focused on
element.definition: A code or group definition that describes the intended subject of the event definition.

binding.name: SubjectType
binding.description: The possible types of subjects for an event (E.g. Patient, Practitioner, Organization, Location, etc.).

element.name: date
element.definition: The date (and optionally time) when the event definition was published. The date must change when the business version changes and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the event definition changes.
element.comment: Note that this is not the same as the resource last-modified-date, since the resource may be a secondary representation of the event definition. Additional specific dates may be added as extensions or be found by consulting Provenances associated with past versions of the resource.

element.name: publisher
element.description: Name of the publisher (organization or individual)
element.definition: The name of the organization or individual that published the event definition.
element.comment: Usually an organization but may be an individual. The publisher (or steward) of the event definition is the organization or individual primarily responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the event definition. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the event definition. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.

element.name: contact
element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
element.comment: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number, etc.

element.name: description
element.description: Natural language description of the event definition
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the event definition from a consumer's perspective.
element.comment: This description can be used to capture details such as why the event definition was built, comments about misuse, instructions for clinical use and interpretation, literature references, examples from the paper world, etc. It is not a rendering of the event definition as conveyed in the 'text' field of the resource itself. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context (e.g. the language of the event definition is presumed to be the predominant language in the place the event definition was created).

element.name: useContext
element.description: The context that the content is intended to support
element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate event definition instances.
element.comment: When multiple useContexts are specified, there is no expectation that all or any of the contexts apply.

element.name: jurisdiction
element.description: Intended jurisdiction for event definition (if applicable)
element.definition: A legal or geographic region in which the event definition is intended to be used.
element.comment: It may be possible for the event definition to be used in jurisdictions other than those for which it was originally designed or intended.

binding.name: Jurisdiction
binding.description: Countries and regions within which this artifact is targeted for use.

element.name: purpose
element.description: Why this event definition is defined
element.definition: Explanation of why this event definition is needed and why it has been designed as it has.
element.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the event definition. Instead, it provides traceability of ''why'' the resource is either needed or ''why'' it is defined as it is. This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this event definition.

element.name: usage
element.description: Describes the clinical usage of the event definition
element.definition: A detailed description of how the event definition is used from a clinical perspective.

element.name: copyright
element.definition: A copyright statement relating to the event definition and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the event definition.

element.name: approvalDate
element.description: When the event definition was approved by publisher
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was approved by the publisher. Approval happens once when the content is officially approved for usage.
element.comment: The 'date' element may be more recent than the approval date because of minor changes or editorial corrections.

element.name: lastReviewDate
element.description: When the event definition was last reviewed
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was last reviewed. Review happens periodically after approval but does not change the original approval date.
element.comment: If specified, this date follows the original approval date.

element.name: effectivePeriod
element.description: When the event definition is expected to be used
element.definition: The period during which the event definition content was or is planned to be in active use.
element.comment: The effective period for a event definition determines when the content is applicable for usage and is independent of publication and review dates. For example, a measure intended to be used for the year 2016 might be published in 2015.

element.name: topic
element.definition: Descriptive topics related to the module. Topics provide a high-level categorization of the module that can be useful for filtering and searching.

binding.name: DefinitionTopic
binding.description: High-level categorization of the definition, used for searching, sorting, and filtering.

element.name: author
element.definition: An individiual or organization primarily involved in the creation and maintenance of the content.

element.name: editor
element.definition: An individual or organization primarily responsible for internal coherence of the content.

element.name: reviewer
element.definition: An individual or organization primarily responsible for review of some aspect of the content.

element.name: endorser
element.definition: An individual or organization responsible for officially endorsing the content for use in some setting.

element.name: relatedArtifact
element.definition: Related resources such as additional documentation, justification, or bibliographic references.
element.comment: Each related resource is either an attachment, or a reference to another resource, but not both.

element.name: trigger
element.definition: The trigger element defines when the event occurs. If more than one trigger condition is specified, the event fires whenever any one of the trigger conditions is met.

element.name: url

element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this evidence when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which at which an authoritative instance of this evidence is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the evidence is stored on different servers.
element.comment:
Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid: but real http: addresses are preferred. Multiple instances may share the same URL if they have a distinct version.
The determination of when to create a new version of a resource (same url, new version) vs. defining a new artifact is up to the author. Considerations for making this decision are found in [Technical and Business Versions](resource.html#versions).
In some cases, the resource can no longer be found at the stated url, but the url itself cannot change. Implementations can use the [meta.source](resource.html#meta) element to indicate where the current master source of the resource can be found.

element.comment: Typically, this is used for identifiers that can go in an HL7 V3 II (instance identifier) data type, and can then identify this evidence outside of FHIR, where it is not possible to use the logical URI.

To provide a version consistent with the Decision Support Service specification, use the format Major.Minor.Revision (e.g. 1.0.0). element.name: shortTitle

element.name: subtitle

element.name: status
