This is an arbitrary value managed by the terminology capabilities author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence.
element.comment: There may be different terminology capabilities instances that have the same identifier but different versions. The version can be appended to the url in a reference to allow a reference to a particular business version of the terminology capabilities with the format [url]|[version].

element.name: name
element.description: Name for this terminology capabilities (computer friendly)
element.definition: A natural language name identifying the terminology capabilities. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alphanumeric type name to ensure that it is machine-processing friendly.

element.name: title
element.description: Name for this terminology capabilities (human friendly)
element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the terminology capabilities.
element.comment: This name does not need to be machine-processing friendly and may contain punctuation, white-space, etc.

element.name: status
element.definition: The status of this terminology capabilities. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content.
element.comment: Allows filtering of terminology capabilitiess that are appropriate for use versus not.This is not intended for use with actual capability statements, but where capability statements are used to describe possible or desired systems.

binding.name: PublicationStatus
binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.name: experimental
element.description: For testing purposes, not real usage
element.definition: A Boolean value to indicate that this terminology capabilities is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing) and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.comment: Allows filtering of terminology capabilitiess that are appropriate for use versus not.

element.name: date
element.definition: The date (and optionally time) when the terminology capabilities was published. The date must change when the business version changes and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the terminology capabilities changes.
element.comment: Note that this is not the same as the resource last-modified-date, since the resource may be a secondary representation of the terminology capabilities. Additional specific dates may be added as extensions or be found by consulting Provenances associated with past versions of the resource.

element.name: publisher
element.description: Name of the publisher (organization or individual)
element.definition: The name of the organization or individual that published the terminology capabilities.
element.comment: Usually an organization but may be an individual. The publisher (or steward) of the terminology capabilities is the organization or individual primarily responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the terminology capabilities. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the terminology capabilities. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.

element.name: contact
element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
element.comment: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number, etc.

element.name: description
element.description: Natural language description of the terminology capabilities
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the terminology capabilities from a consumer's perspective. Typically, this is used when the capability statement describes a desired rather than an actual solution, for example as a formal expression of requirements as part of an RFP.
element.comment: This description can be used to capture details such as why the terminology capabilities was built, comments about misuse, instructions for clinical use and interpretation, literature references, examples from the paper world, etc. It is not a rendering of the terminology capabilities as conveyed in the 'text' field of the resource itself. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context (e.g. the language of the terminology capabilities is presumed to be the predominant language in the place the terminology capabilities was created).This does not need to be populated if the description is adequately implied by the software or implementation details.

element.name: useContext
element.description: The context that the content is intended to support
element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate terminology capabilities instances.
element.comment: When multiple useContexts are specified, there is no expectation that all or any of the contexts apply.

element.name: jurisdiction
element.description: Intended jurisdiction for terminology capabilities (if applicable)
element.definition: A legal or geographic region in which the terminology capabilities is intended to be used.
element.comment: It may be possible for the terminology capabilities to be used in jurisdictions other than those for which it was originally designed or intended.

binding.name: Jurisdiction
binding.description: Countries and regions within which this artifact is targeted for use.

element.name: purpose
element.description: Why this terminology capabilities is defined
element.definition: Explanation of why this terminology capabilities is needed and why it has been designed as it has.
element.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the terminology capabilities. Instead, it provides traceability of ''why'' the resource is either needed or ''why'' it is defined as it is. This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this terminology capabilities.

element.name: copyright
element.definition: A copyright statement relating to the terminology capabilities and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the terminology capabilities.

element.name: kind
element.definition: The way that this statement is intended to be used, to describe an actual running instance of software, a particular product (kind, not instance of software) or a class of implementation (e.g. a desired purchase).

binding.name: CapabilityStatementKind
binding.description: How a capability statement is intended to be used.

element.name: software
element.description: Software that is covered by this terminology capability statement
element.definition: Software that is covered by this terminology capability statement. It is used when the statement describes the capabilities of a particular software version, independent of an installation.

element.name: implementation
element.description: If this describes a specific instance
element.definition: Identifies a specific implementation instance that is described by the terminology capability statement - i.e. a particular installation, rather than the capabilities of a software program.

element.name: lockedDate
element.definition: Whether the server supports lockedDate.

element.name: codeSystem
element.description: A code system supported by the server
element.definition: Identifies a code system that is supported by the server. If there is a no code system URL, then this declares the general assumptions a client can make about support for any CodeSystem resource.
element.comment: The code system - identified by its system URL - may also be declared explicitly as a Code System Resource at /CodeSystem, but it might not be.

constraint.name: tcp-1
constraint.message: If there is more than one version, a version code must be defined

element.name: expansion
element.definition: Information about the [ValueSet/$expand](valueset-operation-expand.html) operation.

element.name: codeSearch
element.definition: The degree to which the server supports the code search parameter on ValueSet, if it is supported.
element.comment: See notes on the [ValueSet](valueset.html#) resource.

binding.name: CodeSearchSupport
binding.description: The degree to which the server supports the code search parameter on ValueSet, if it is supported.

element.name: validateCode
element.definition: Information about the [ValueSet/$validate-code](valueset-operation-validate-code.html) operation.

element.name: translation
element.definition: Information about the [ConceptMap/$translate](conceptmap-operation-translate.html) operation.

element.name: closure
element.definition: Whether the $closure operation is supported.

element.name: translation
element.definition: If cross-system closure is supported.

element.name: uri
element.definition: URI for the Code System.

element.name: version
element.definition: For the code system, a list of versions that are supported by the server.
element.comment: Language translations might not be available for all codes.

element.name: subsumption
element.definition: True if subsumption is supported for this version of the code system.

element.name: code
element.definition: For version-less code systems, there should be a single version with no identifier.

element.name: isDefault
element.description: If this is the default version for this code system
element.definition: If this is the default version for this code system.

element.name: compositional
element.definition: If the compositional grammar defined by the code system is supported.

element.name: language
element.definition: Language Displays supported.

element.name: filter
element.definition: Filter Properties supported.

element.name: property
element.definition: Properties supported for $lookup.

element.name: code
element.definition: Code of the property supported.

element.name: op
element.definition: Operations supported for the property.

element.name: hierarchical
element.description: Whether the server can return nested value sets
element.definition: Whether the server can return nested value sets.

element.name: paging
element.description: Whether the server supports paging on expansion
element.definition: Whether the server supports paging on expansion.

element.name: incomplete
element.definition: Allow request for incomplete expansions?

element.name: parameter
element.definition: Supported expansion parameter.

element.name: textFilter
element.definition: Documentation about text searching works.
element.comment: This documentation should cover things like case sensitivity, use of punctuation if not ignored, what wild cards are supported (if any), whether text is starts with or contains, and whether word order matters.

element.name: name
element.definition: Expansion Parameter name.

element.name: documentation
element.definition: Description of support for parameter.

element.name: description
element.definition: Information about the specific installation that this terminology capability statement relates to.

element.name: url
element.definition: An absolute base URL for the implementation.

element.name: name
element.description: A name the software is known by
element.definition: Name the software is known by.

element.name: version
element.definition: The version identifier for the software covered by this statement.
element.comment: If possible, a version should be specified, as statements are likely to be different for different versions of software.

element.name: needsMap
element.description: Whether the client must identify the map
element.definition: Whether the client must identify the map.

element.name: translations
element.definition: Whether translations are validated.

element.name: identifier
element.definition: Identifier for the TestScript assigned for external purposes outside the context of FHIR.

element.name: name
element.description: Informal name of the executed TestScript
element.definition: A free text natural language name identifying the executed TestScript.
element.comment: Not expected to be globally unique.

element.name: status
element.definition: The current state of this test report.
element.comment:
The status represents where the execution is currently within the test script execution life cycle.
This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the resource as not currently valid.

binding.name: TestReportStatus
binding.description: The current status of the test report.

element.name: testScript
element.description: Reference to the version-specific TestScript that was executed to produce this TestReport
element.definition: Ideally this is an absolute URL that is used to identify the version-specific TestScript that was executed, matching the `TestScript.url`.

element.name: result
element.definition: The overall result from the execution of the TestScript.
element.comment: The pass and fail result represents a completed test script execution. The pending result represents a test script execution that has not yet started or is currently in progress.

binding.name: TestReportResult
binding.description: The reported execution result.

element.name: score
element.description: The final score (percentage of tests passed) resulting from the execution of the TestScript
element.definition: The final score (percentage of tests passed) resulting from the execution of the TestScript.

element.name: tester
element.description: Name of the tester producing this report (Organization or individual)
element.definition: Name of the tester producing this report (Organization or individual).
element.comment: Usually an organization, but may be an individual. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.

element.name: issued
element.description: When the TestScript was executed and this TestReport was generated
element.definition: When the TestScript was executed and this TestReport was generated.
element.comment: Additional specific dates may be added as extensions.

element.name: participant
element.description: A participant in the test execution, either the execution engine, a client, or a server
element.definition: A participant in the test execution, either the execution engine, a client, or a server.

element.name: setup
element.description: The results of the series of required setup operations before the tests were executed
element.definition: The results of the series of required setup operations before the tests were executed.

element.name: test
element.description: A test executed from the test script
element.definition: A test executed from the test script.

element.name: teardown
element.description: The results of running the series of required clean up steps
element.definition: The results of the series of operations required to clean up after all the tests were executed (successfully or otherwise).

element.name: type
element.definition: The type of participant.

binding.name: TestReportParticipantType
binding.description: The type of participant.

element.name: uri
element.description: The uri of the participant. An absolute URL is preferred
element.definition: The uri of the participant. An absolute URL is preferred.

element.name: display
element.description: The display name of the participant
element.definition: The display name of the participant.

element.name: action
element.description: A setup operation or assert that was executed
element.definition: Action would contain either an operation or an assertion.
element.comment: An action should contain either an operation or an assertion but not both. It can contain any number of variables.

constraint.name: inv-1
constraint.message: Setup action SHALL contain either an operation or assert but not both.

element.name: operation
element.definition: The operation performed.

element.name: assert
element.definition: The results of the assertion performed on the previous operations.

element.name: result
element.definition: The result of this assertion.

binding.name: TestReportActionResult
binding.description: The results of executing an action.

element.name: message
element.description: A message associated with the result
element.definition: An explanatory message associated with the result.

element.name: detail
element.description: A link to further details on the result
element.definition: A link to further details on the result.

element.name: result
element.definition: The result of this operation.

binding.name: TestReportActionResult
binding.description: The results of executing an action.

element.name: message
element.description: A message associated with the result
element.definition: An explanatory message associated with the result.

element.name: detail
element.description: A link to further details on the result
element.definition: A link to further details on the result.

element.name: action
element.description: One or more teardown operations performed
element.definition: The teardown action will only contain an operation.
element.comment: An action should contain either an operation or an assertion but not both. It can contain any number of variables.

element.name: operation
element.definition: An operation would involve a REST request to a server.

element.name: name
element.definition: The name of this test used for tracking/logging purposes by test engines.

element.name: description
element.description: Tracking/reporting short description of the test
element.definition: A short description of the test used by test engines for tracking and reporting purposes.

element.name: action
element.description: A test operation or assert that was performed
element.definition: Action would contain either an operation or an assertion.
element.comment: An action should contain either an operation or an assertion but not both. It can contain any number of variables.

constraint.name: inv-2
constraint.message: Test action SHALL contain either an operation or assert but not both.

element.name: operation
element.definition: An operation would involve a REST request to a server.

element.name: assert
element.definition: The results of the assertion performed on the previous operations.

element.name: url
element.description: Canonical identifier for this test script, represented as a URI (globally unique)
element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this test script when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which at which an authoritative instance of this test script is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the test script is stored on different servers.
element.comment:
Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid: but real http: addresses are preferred. Multiple instances may share the same URL if they have a distinct version.
The determination of when to create a new version of a resource (same url, new version) vs. defining a new artifact is up to the author. Considerations for making this decision are found in [Technical and Business Versions](resource.html#versions).
In some cases, the resource can no longer be found at the stated url, but the url itself cannot change. Implementations can use the [meta.source](resource.html#meta) element to indicate where the current master source of the resource can be found.

element.name: identifier
element.description: Additional identifier for the test script
element.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this test script when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
element.comment: Typically, this is used for identifiers that can go in an HL7 V3 II (instance identifier) data type, and can then identify this test script outside of FHIR, where it is not possible to use the logical URI.

element.name: version
element.description: Business version of the test script
element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the test script when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the test script author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence.
element.comment: There may be different test script instances that have the same identifier but different versions. The version can be appended to the url in a reference to allow a reference to a particular business version of the test script with the format [url]|[version].

element.name: name
element.description: Name for this test script (computer friendly)
element.definition: A natural language name identifying the test script. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alphanumeric type name to ensure that it is machine-processing friendly.

element.name: title
element.description: Name for this test script (human friendly)
element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the test script.
element.comment: This name does not need to be machine-processing friendly and may contain punctuation, white-space, etc.

element.name: status
element.definition: The status of this test script. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content.
element.comment: Allows filtering of test scripts that are appropriate for use versus not.

binding.name: PublicationStatus
binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.name: experimental
element.description: For testing purposes, not real usage
element.definition: A Boolean value to indicate that this test script is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing) and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.comment: Allows filtering of test scripts that are appropriate for use versus not.

element.name: date
element.definition: The date (and optionally time) when the test script was published. The date must change when the business version changes and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the test script changes.
element.comment: Note that this is not the same as the resource last-modified-date, since the resource may be a secondary representation of the test script. Additional specific dates may be added as extensions or be found by consulting Provenances associated with past versions of the resource.

element.name: publisher
element.description: Name of the publisher (organization or individual)
element.definition: The name of the organization or individual that published the test script.
element.comment: Usually an organization but may be an individual. The publisher (or steward) of the test script is the organization or individual primarily responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the test script. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the test script. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.

element.name: contact
element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
element.comment: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number, etc.

element.name: description
element.description: Natural language description of the test script
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the test script from a consumer's perspective.
element.comment: This description can be used to capture details such as why the test script was built, comments about misuse, instructions for clinical use and interpretation, literature references, examples from the paper world, etc. It is not a rendering of the test script as conveyed in the 'text' field of the resource itself. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context (e.g. the language of the test script is presumed to be the predominant language in the place the test script was created).

element.name: useContext
element.description: The context that the content is intended to support
element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate test script instances.
element.comment: When multiple useContexts are specified, there is no expectation that all or any of the contexts apply.

element.name: jurisdiction
element.description: Intended jurisdiction for test script (if applicable)
element.definition: A legal or geographic region in which the test script is intended to be used.
element.comment: It may be possible for the test script to be used in jurisdictions other than those for which it was originally designed or intended.

binding.name: Jurisdiction
binding.description: Countries and regions within which this artifact is targeted for use.

element.name: purpose
element.description: Why this test script is defined
element.definition: Explanation of why this test script is needed and why it has been designed as it has.
element.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the test script. Instead, it provides traceability of ''why'' the resource is either needed or ''why'' it is defined as it is. This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this test script.

element.name: copyright
element.definition: A copyright statement relating to the test script and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the test script.

element.name: origin
element.description: An abstract server representing a client or sender in a message exchange
element.definition: An abstract server used in operations within this test script in the origin element.
element.comment: The purpose of this element is to define the profile of an origin element used elsewhere in the script. Test engines could then use the origin-profile mapping to offer a filtered list of test systems that can serve as the sender for the interaction.

element.name: destination
element.description: An abstract server representing a destination or receiver in a message exchange
element.definition: An abstract server used in operations within this test script in the destination element.
element.comment: The purpose of this element is to define the profile of a destination element used elsewhere in the script. Test engines could then use the destination-profile mapping to offer a filtered list of test systems that can serve as the receiver for the interaction.

element.name: metadata
element.description: Required capability that is assumed to function correctly on the FHIR server being tested
element.definition: The required capability must exist and are assumed to function correctly on the FHIR server being tested.

constraint.name: tst-4
constraint.message: TestScript metadata capability SHALL contain required or validated or both.

element.name: fixture
element.description: Fixture in the test script - by reference (uri)
element.definition: Fixture in the test script - by reference (uri). All fixtures are required for the test script to execute.

element.name: profile
element.definition: Reference to the profile to be used for validation.
element.comment: See http://build.fhir.org/resourcelist.html for complete list of resource types.

element.name: variable
element.definition: Variable is set based either on element value in response body or on header field value in the response headers.
element.comment: Variables would be set based either on XPath/JSONPath expressions against fixtures (static and response), or headerField evaluations against response headers. If variable evaluates to nodelist or anything other than a primitive value, then test engine would report an error. Variables would be used to perform clean replacements in "operation.params", "operation.requestHeader.value", and "operation.url" element values during operation calls and in "assert.value" during assertion evaluations. This limits the places that test engines would need to look for placeholders "${}". Variables are scoped to the whole script. They are NOT evaluated at declaration. They are evaluated by test engine when used for substitutions in "operation.params", "operation.requestHeader.value", and "operation.url" element values during operation calls and in "assert.value" during assertion evaluations. See example testscript-search.xml.

constraint.name: tst-3
constraint.message: Variable can only contain one of expression, headerField or path.

element.name: setup
element.description: A series of required setup operations before tests are executed
element.definition: A series of required setup operations before tests are executed.

element.name: test
element.definition: A test in this script.

element.name: teardown
element.description: A series of required clean up steps
element.definition: A series of operations required to clean up after all the tests are executed (successfully or otherwise).

element.name: index
element.description: The index of the abstract destination server starting at 1
element.definition: Abstract name given to a destination server in this test script. The name is provided as a number starting at 1.
element.comment:
A given destination index (e.g. 1) can appear only once in the list (e.g. Destination 1 cannot be specified twice ... once as Form-Manager and again as Form-Processor within the same script as that could get confusing during test configuration).
Different destination indices could play the same actor in the same test script (e.g. You could have two different test systems acting as Form-Manager).
The destination indices provided elsewhere in the test script must be one of these destination indices.

element.name: profile
element.definition: The type of destination profile the test system supports.
element.comment: Must be a "receiver"/"server" profile.

binding.name: TestScriptProfileDestinationType
binding.description: The type of destination profile the test system supports.

element.name: autocreate
element.description: Whether or not to implicitly create the fixture during setup
element.definition: Whether or not to implicitly create the fixture during setup. If true, the fixture is automatically created on each server being tested during setup, therefore no create operation is required for this fixture in the TestScript.setup section.

element.name: autodelete
element.description: Whether or not to implicitly delete the fixture during teardown
element.definition: Whether or not to implicitly delete the fixture during teardown. If true, the fixture is automatically deleted on each server being tested during teardown, therefore no delete operation is required for this fixture in the TestScript.teardown section.

element.name: resource
element.definition: Reference to the resource (containing the contents of the resource needed for operations).
element.comment: See http://build.fhir.org/resourcelist.html for complete list of resource types.

element.name: link
element.definition: A link to the FHIR specification that this test is covering.

element.name: capability
element.description: Capabilities that are assumed to function correctly on the FHIR server being tested
element.definition: Capabilities that must exist and are assumed to function correctly on the FHIR server being tested.
element.comment: When the metadata capabilities section is defined at TestScript.metadata or at TestScript.setup.metadata, and the server's conformance statement does not contain the elements defined in the minimal conformance statement, then all the tests in the TestScript are skipped. When the metadata capabilities section is defined at TestScript.test.metadata and the server's conformance statement does not contain the elements defined in the minimal conformance statement, then only that test is skipped. The "metadata.capabilities.required" and "metadata.capabilities.validated" elements only indicate whether the capabilities are the primary focus of the test script or not. They do not impact the skipping logic. Capabilities whose "metadata.capabilities.validated" flag is true are the primary focus of the test script.

element.name: required
element.definition: Whether or not the test execution will require the given capabilities of the server in order for this test script to execute.

element.name: validated
element.definition: Whether or not the test execution will validate the given capabilities of the server in order for this test script to execute.

element.name: description
element.description: The expected capabilities of the server
element.definition: Description of the capabilities that this test script is requiring the server to support.

element.name: origin
element.description: Which origin server these requirements apply to
element.definition: Which origin server these requirements apply to.

element.name: destination
element.description: Which server these requirements apply to
element.definition: Which server these requirements apply to.

element.name: link
element.definition: Links to the FHIR specification that describes this interaction and the resources involved in more detail.

element.name: capabilities
element.definition: Minimum capabilities required of server for test script to execute successfully. If server does not meet at a minimum the referenced capability statement, then all tests in this script are skipped.
element.comment: The conformance statement of the server has to contain at a minimum the contents of the reference pointed to by this element.

element.name: url
element.definition: URL to a particular requirement or feature within the FHIR specification.

element.name: description
element.definition: Short description of the link.

element.name: index
element.description: The index of the abstract origin server starting at 1
element.definition: Abstract name given to an origin server in this test script. The name is provided as a number starting at 1.
element.comment:
A given origin index (e.g. 1) can appear only once in the list (e.g. Origin 1 cannot be specified twice ... once as FormFiller and again as FormProcessor within the same script as that could get confusing during test configuration).
Different origin indices could play the same actor in the same test script (e.g. You could have two different test systems acting as Form-Filler).
The origin indices provided elsewhere in the test script must be one of these origin indices.

element.name: profile
element.definition: The type of origin profile the test system supports.
element.comment: Must be a "sender"/"client" profile.

binding.name: TestScriptProfileOriginType
binding.description: The type of origin profile the test system supports.

element.name: action
element.description: A setup operation or assert to perform
element.definition: Action would contain either an operation or an assertion.
element.comment: An action should contain either an operation or an assertion but not both. It can contain any number of variables.

constraint.name: tst-1
constraint.message: Setup action SHALL contain either an operation or assert but not both.

element.name: operation
element.definition: The operation to perform.

constraint.name: tst-7
constraint.message: Setup operation SHALL contain either sourceId or targetId or params or url.

expression.expression: sourceId.exists() or (targetId.count() + url.count() + params.count() = 1) or (type.code in ('capabilities' |'search' | 'transaction' | 'history'))

element.name: assert
element.definition: Evaluates the results of previous operations to determine if the server under test behaves appropriately.
element.comment: In order to evaluate an assertion, the request, response, and results of the most recently executed operation must always be maintained by the test engine.

constraint.name: tst-12
constraint.message: Setup action assert response and responseCode SHALL be empty when direction equals request

expression.expression: (response.empty() and responseCode.empty() and direction = 'request') or direction.empty() or direction = 'response'

constraint.name: tst-5
constraint.message: Only a single assertion SHALL be present within setup action assert element.

expression.expression: extension.exists() or (contentType.count() + expression.count() + headerField.count() + minimumId.count() + navigationLinks.count() + path.count() + requestMethod.count() + resource.count() + responseCode.count() + response.count() + validateProfileId.count() <=1)

constraint.name: tst-10
constraint.message: Setup action assert SHALL contain either compareToSourceId and compareToSourceExpression, compareToSourceId and compareToSourcePath or neither.

element.name: label
element.definition: The label would be used for tracking/logging purposes by test engines.
element.comment: This has no impact on the verification itself.

element.name: description
element.definition: The description would be used by test engines for tracking and reporting purposes.
element.comment: This has no impact on the verification itself.

element.name: direction
element.definition: The direction to use for the assertion.
element.comment: If the direction is specified as "response" (the default), then the processing of this assert is against the received response message. If the direction is specified as "request", then the processing of this assert is against the sent request message.

binding.name: AssertionDirectionType
binding.description: The type of direction to use for assertion.

element.name: compareToSourceId
element.description: Id of the source fixture to be evaluated
element.definition: Id of the source fixture used as the contents to be evaluated by either the "source/expression" or "sourceId/path" definition.

element.name: compareToSourceExpression
element.description: The FHIRPath expression to evaluate against the source fixture
element.definition: The FHIRPath expression to evaluate against the source fixture. When compareToSourceId is defined, either compareToSourceExpression or compareToSourcePath must be defined, but not both.
element.comment: Thefhirpath expression to be evaluated against the expected fixture to compare to. Ignored if "assert.value" is used. The evaluation will be done before the assertion is evaluated.

element.name: compareToSourcePath
element.description: XPath or JSONPath expression to evaluate against the source fixture
element.definition: XPath or JSONPath expression to evaluate against the source fixture. When compareToSourceId is defined, either compareToSourceExpression or compareToSourcePath must be defined, but not both.
element.comment: The XPath or JSONPath expression to be evaluated against the expected fixture to compare to. Ignored if "assert.value" is used. The evaluation will be done before the assertion is evaluated.

element.name: contentType
element.description: Mime type to compare against the 'Content-Type' header
element.definition: The mime-type contents to compare against the request or response message 'Content-Type' header.
element.comment: If this is specified, then test engine shall confirm that the content-type of the last operation's headers is set to this value. If "assert.sourceId" element is specified, then the evaluation will be done against the headers mapped to that sourceId (and not the last operation's headers). If you'd like to have more control over the string, then use 'assert.headerField' instead.

binding.name: MimeType
binding.description: The mime type of an attachment. Any valid mime type is allowed.

element.name: expression
element.description: The FHIRPath expression to be evaluated
element.definition: The FHIRPath expression to be evaluated against the request or response message contents - HTTP headers and payload.
element.comment: If both "expression" and a "fixtureId" are specified, then the expression will be evaluated against the request or response body mapped to the fixtureId. If "expression" is specified and a "fixtureId" is not, then the expression will be evaluated against the response body of the last operation. Test engines are to store the request and response body and headers of the last operation at all times for subsequent assertions.

element.name: headerField
element.definition: The HTTP header field name e.g. 'Location'.
element.comment: If "headerField" is specified then "value" must be specified. If "sourceId" is not specified, then "headerField" will be evaluated against the last operation's response headers. Test engines are to keep track of the last operation's response body and response headers.

element.name: minimumId
element.description: Fixture Id of minimum content resource
element.definition: The ID of a fixture. Asserts that the response contains at a minimum the fixture specified by minimumId.
element.comment: Asserts that the response contains all the element/content in another fixture pointed to by minimumId. This can be a statically defined fixture or one that is dynamically set via responseId.

element.name: navigationLinks
element.definition: Whether or not the test execution performs validation on the bundle navigation links.
element.comment: Asserts that the Bundle contains first, last, and next links.

element.name: operator
element.description: equals | notEquals | in | notIn | greaterThan | lessThan | empty | notEmpty | contains | notContains | eval
element.definition: The operator type defines the conditional behavior of the assert. If not defined, the default is equals.
element.comment: Operators are useful especially for negative testing. If operator is not specified, then the "equals" operator is assumed; e.g. ``` ```.

binding.name: AssertionOperatorType
binding.description: The type of operator to use for assertion.

element.name: path
element.definition: The XPath or JSONPath expression to be evaluated against the fixture representing the response received from server.
element.comment: If both "path" and a "fixtureId" are specified, then the path will be evaluated against the request or response body mapped to the fixtureId. If "path" is specified and a "fixtureId" is not, then the path will be evaluated against the response body of the last operation. Test engines are to store the request and response body and headers of the last operation at all times for subsequent assertions.

element.name: requestMethod
element.description: delete | get | options | patch | post | put | head
element.definition: The request method or HTTP operation code to compare against that used by the client system under test.
element.comment: If "requestMethod" is specified then it will be used in place of "value". The "requestMethod" will evaluate against the last operation's request HTTP operation.

binding.name: TestScriptRequestMethodCode
binding.description: The allowable request method or HTTP operation codes.

element.name: requestURL
element.definition: The value to use in a comparison against the request URL path string.
element.comment: If "requestURL" is specified then it will be used in place of "value". The "requestURL" will evaluate against the last operation's full request URL path string.

element.name: resource
element.definition: The type of the resource. See http://build.fhir.org/resourcelist.html.
element.comment: This will be expected resource type in response body e.g. in read, vread, search, etc. See http://build.fhir.org/resourcelist.html for complete list of resource types; e.g. <assert > <resourceType value="Patient" </assert>.

binding.name: FHIRDefinedType
binding.description: A list of all the concrete types defined in this version of the FHIR specification - Data Types and Resource Types.

element.name: response
element.description: okay | created | noContent | notModified | bad | forbidden | notFound | methodNotAllowed | conflict | gone | preconditionFailed | unprocessable
element.definition: okay | created | noContent | notModified | bad | forbidden | notFound | methodNotAllowed | conflict | gone | preconditionFailed | unprocessable.
element.comment: This is a shorter way of achieving similar verifications via "assert.responseCode". If you need more control, then use "assert.responseCode" e.g. <assert> <contentType value="json" /> <response value="okay"/> </assert>.

binding.name: AssertionResponseTypes
binding.description: The type of response code to use for assertion.

element.name: responseCode
element.definition: The value of the HTTP response code to be tested.
element.comment: To be used with "operator" attribute value. Asserts that the response code equals this value if "operator" is not specified. If the operator is "in" or "notIn" then the responseCode would be a comma-separated list of values e.g. "200,201". Otherwise, it's expected to be a numeric value. If "fixture" is not specified, then the "responseBodyId" value of the last operation is assumed.

element.name: sourceId
element.description: Fixture Id of source expression or headerField
element.definition: Fixture to evaluate the XPath/JSONPath expression or the headerField against.
element.comment: This can be a statically defined fixture (at the top of the testscript) or a dynamically set fixture created by responseId of the action.operation element.

element.name: validateProfileId
element.description: Profile Id of validation profile reference
element.definition: The ID of the Profile to validate against.
element.comment: The ID of a Profile fixture. Asserts that the response is valid according to the Profile specified by validateProfileId.

element.name: value
element.definition: The value to compare to.
element.comment: The string-representation of a number, string, or boolean that is expected. Test engines do have to look for placeholders (${}) and replace the variable placeholders with the variable values at runtime before comparing this value to the actual value.

element.name: warningOnly
element.description: Will this assert produce a warning only on error?
element.definition: Whether or not the test execution will produce a warning only on error for this assert.
element.comment: If this element is specified and it is true, then assertion failures can be logged by test engine but should not stop the test script execution from proceeding. There are likely cases where the spec is not clear on what should happen. If the spec says something is optional (maybe a response header for example), but a server doesnt do it, we could choose to issue a warning.

element.name: type
element.description: The operation code type that will be executed
element.definition: Server interaction or operation type.
element.comment: See http://build.fhir.org/http.html for list of server interactions.

binding.name: TestScriptOperationCode
binding.description: The allowable operation code types.

element.name: resource
element.definition: The type of the resource. See http://build.fhir.org/resourcelist.html.
element.comment: If "url" element is specified, then "targetId", "params", and "resource" elements will be ignored as "url" element will have everything needed for constructing the request url. If "params" element is specified, then "targetId" element is ignored. For FHIR operations that require a resource (e.g. "read" and "vread" operations), the "resource" element must be specified when "params" element is specified. If "url" and "params" elements are absent, then the request url will be constructed from "targetId" fixture if present. For "read" operation, the resource and id values will be extracted from "targetId" fixture and used to construct the url. For "vread" and "history" operations, the versionId value will also be used.

binding.name: FHIRDefinedType
binding.description: A list of all the concrete types defined in this version of the FHIR specification - Data Types and Resource Types.

element.name: label
element.definition: The label would be used for tracking/logging purposes by test engines.
element.comment: This has no impact on the verification itself.

element.name: description
element.definition: The description would be used by test engines for tracking and reporting purposes.
element.comment: This has no impact on the verification itself.

element.name: accept
element.description: Mime type to accept in the payload of the response, with charset etc.
element.definition: The mime-type to use for RESTful operation in the 'Accept' header.
element.comment: If this is specified, then test engine shall set the 'Accept' header to the corresponding value. If you'd like to explicitly set the 'Accept' to some other value then use the 'requestHeader' element.

binding.name: MimeType
binding.description: The mime type of an attachment. Any valid mime type is allowed.

element.name: contentType
element.description: Mime type of the request payload contents, with charset etc.
element.definition: The mime-type to use for RESTful operation in the 'Content-Type' header.
element.comment: If this is specified, then test engine shall set the 'Content-Type' header to the corresponding value. If you'd like to explicitly set the 'Content-Type' to some other value then use the 'requestHeader' element.

binding.name: MimeType
binding.description: The mime type of an attachment. Any valid mime type is allowed.

element.name: destination
element.definition: The server where the request message is destined for. Must be one of the server numbers listed in TestScript.destination section.
element.comment: If multiple TestScript.destination elements are defined and operation.destination is undefined, test engine will report an error as it cannot determine what destination to use for the exchange.

element.name: encodeRequestUrl
element.description: Whether or not to send the request url in encoded format
element.definition: Whether or not to implicitly send the request url in encoded format. The default is true to match the standard RESTful client behavior. Set to false when communicating with a server that does not support encoded url paths.

element.name: method
element.description: delete | get | options | patch | post | put | head
element.definition: The HTTP method the test engine MUST use for this operation regardless of any other operation details.
element.comment: The primary purpose of the explicit HTTP method is support of HTTP POST method invocation of the FHIR search. Other uses will include support of negative testing.

binding.name: TestScriptRequestMethodCode
binding.description: The allowable request method or HTTP operation codes.

element.name: origin
element.definition: The server where the request message originates from. Must be one of the server numbers listed in TestScript.origin section.
element.comment: If absent, test engine will send the message. When present, test engine will not send the request message but will wait for the request message to be sent from this origin server.

element.name: params
element.definition: Path plus parameters after [type]. Used to set parts of the request URL explicitly.
element.comment: If "url" element is specified, then "targetId", "params", and "resource" elements will be ignored as "url" element will have everything needed for constructing the request url. If "params" element is specified, then "targetId" element is ignored. For FHIR operations that require a resource (e.g. "read" and "vread" operations), the "resource" element must be specified when "params" element is specified. If "url" and "params" elements are absent, then the request url will be constructed from "targetId" fixture if present. For "read" operation, the resource and id values will be extracted from "targetId" fixture and used to construct the url. For "vread" and "history" operations, the versionId value will also be used. Test engines would append whatever is specified for "params" to the URL after the resource type without tampering with the string (beyond encoding the URL for HTTP). The "params" element does not correspond exactly to "search parameters". Nor is it the "path". It corresponds to the part of the URL that comes after the [type] (when "resource" element is specified); e.g. It corresponds to "/[id]/_history/[vid] {?_format=[mime-type]}" in the following operation: GET [base]/[type]/[id]/_history/[vid] {?_format=[mime-type]} Test engines do have to look for placeholders (${}) and replace the variable placeholders with the variable values at runtime before sending the request.

element.name: requestHeader
element.description: Each operation can have one or more header elements
element.definition: Header elements would be used to set HTTP headers.
element.comment: This gives control to test-script writers to set headers explicitly based on test requirements. It will allow for testing using: - "If-Modified-Since" and "If-None-Match" headers. See http://build.fhir.org/http.html#2.1.0.5.1 - "If-Match" header. See http://build.fhir.org/http.html#2.1.0.11 - Conditional Create using "If-None-Exist". See http://build.fhir.org/http.html#2.1.0.13.1 - Invalid "Content-Type" header for negative testing. - etc.

element.name: requestId
element.definition: The fixture id (maybe new) to map to the request.
element.comment: If a requestId is supplied, then the resulting request (both headers and body) is mapped to the fixture ID (which may be entirely new and previously undeclared) designated by "requestId". If requestId is not specified, it is the test engine's responsibility to store the request and use it as the requestId in subsequent assertions when assertion path and/or headerField is specified, direction is equal to request, and the requestId in not specified.

element.name: responseId
element.definition: The fixture id (maybe new) to map to the response.
element.comment: If a responseId is supplied, and the server responds, then the resulting response (both headers and body) is mapped to the fixture ID (which may be entirely new and previously undeclared) designated by "responseId". If responseId is not specified, it is the test engine's responsibility to store the response and use it as the responseId in subsequent assertions when assertion path and/or headerField is specified and the responseId is not specified.

element.name: sourceId
element.description: Fixture Id of body for PUT and POST requests
element.definition: The id of the fixture used as the body of a PUT or POST request.

element.name: targetId
element.description: Id of fixture used for extracting the [id], [type], and [vid] for GET requests
element.definition: Id of fixture used for extracting the [id], [type], and [vid] for GET requests.
element.comment: If "url" element is specified, then "targetId", "params", and "resource" elements will be ignored as "url" element will have everything needed for constructing the request url. If "params" element is specified, then "targetId" element is ignored. For FHIR operations that require a resource (e.g. "read" and "vread" operations), the "resource" element must be specified when "params" element is specified. If "url" and "params" elements are absent, then the request url will be constructed from "targetId" fixture if present. For "read" operation, the resource and id values will be extracted from "targetId" fixture and used to construct the url. For "vread" and "history" operations, the versionId value will also be used.

element.name: url
element.definition: Complete request URL.
element.comment: Used to set the request URL explicitly. If "url" element is defined, then "targetId", "resource", and "params" elements will be ignored. Test engines would use whatever is specified in "url" without tampering with the string (beyond encoding the URL for HTTP). Test engines do have to look for placeholders (${}) and replace the variable placeholders with the variable values at runtime before sending the request.

element.name: field
element.definition: The HTTP header field e.g. "Accept".
element.comment: If header element is specified, then field is required.

element.name: value
element.definition: The value of the header e.g. "application/fhir+xml".
element.comment: If header element is specified, then value is required. No conversions will be done by the test engine e.g. "xml" to "application/fhir+xml". The values will be set in HTTP headers "as-is". Test engines do have to look for placeholders (${}) and replace the variable placeholders with the variable values at runtime before sending the request.

element.name: action
element.description: One or more teardown operations to perform
element.definition: The teardown action will only contain an operation.
element.comment: An action should contain either an operation or an assertion but not both. It can contain any number of variables.

element.name: operation
element.definition: An operation would involve a REST request to a server.

constraint.name: tst-9
constraint.message: Teardown operation SHALL contain either sourceId or targetId or params or url.

expression.expression: sourceId.exists() or (targetId.count() + url.count() + params.count() = 1) or (type.code in ('capabilities' | 'search' | 'transaction' | 'history'))

element.name: name
element.definition: The name of this test used for tracking/logging purposes by test engines.

element.name: description
element.description: Tracking/reporting short description of the test
element.definition: A short description of the test used by test engines for tracking and reporting purposes.

element.name: action
element.description: A test operation or assert to perform
element.definition: Action would contain either an operation or an assertion.
element.comment: An action should contain either an operation or an assertion but not both. It can contain any number of variables.

constraint.name: tst-2
constraint.message: Test action SHALL contain either an operation or assert but not both.

element.name: operation
element.definition: An operation would involve a REST request to a server.

constraint.name: tst-8
constraint.message: Test operation SHALL contain either sourceId or targetId or params or url.

expression.expression: sourceId.exists() or (targetId.count() + url.count() + params.count() = 1) or (type.code in ('capabilities' | 'search' | 'transaction' | 'history'))

element.name: assert
element.definition: Evaluates the results of previous operations to determine if the server under test behaves appropriately.
element.comment: In order to evaluate an assertion, the request, response, and results of the most recently executed operation must always be maintained by the test engine.

constraint.name: tst-11
constraint.message: Test action assert SHALL contain either compareToSourceId and compareToSourceExpression, compareToSourceId and compareToSourcePath or neither.

constraint.name: tst-13
constraint.message: Test action assert response and response and responseCode SHALL be empty when direction equals request

expression.expression: (response.empty() and responseCode.empty() and direction = 'request') or direction.empty() or direction = 'response'

constraint.name: tst-6
constraint.message: Only a single assertion SHALL be present within test action assert element.

expression.expression: extension.exists() or (contentType.count() + expression.count() + headerField.count() + minimumId.count() + navigationLinks.count() + path.count() + requestMethod.count() + resource.count() + responseCode.count() + response.count() + validateProfileId.count() <=1)

element.name: name
element.definition: Descriptive name for this variable.
element.comment: Placeholders would contain the variable name wrapped in ${} in "operation.params", "operation.requestHeader.value", and "operation.url" elements. These placeholders would need to be replaced by the variable value before the operation is executed.

element.name: defaultValue
element.description: Default, hard-coded, or user-defined value for this variable
element.definition: A default, hard-coded, or user-defined value for this variable.
element.comment: The purpose of this element is to allow for a pre-defined value that can be used as a default or as an override value. Test engines can optionally use this as a placeholder for user-defined execution time values.

element.name: description
element.description: Natural language description of the variable
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the variable and its purpose.

element.name: expression
element.description: The FHIRPath expression against the fixture body
element.definition: The FHIRPath expression to evaluate against the fixture body. When variables are defined, only one of either expression, headerField or path must be specified.
element.comment: If headerField is defined, then the variable will be evaluated against the headers that sourceId is pointing to. If expression or path is defined, then the variable will be evaluated against the fixture body that sourceId is pointing to. It is an error to define any combination of expression, headerField and path.

element.name: headerField
element.description: HTTP header field name for source
element.definition: Will be used to grab the HTTP header field value from the headers that sourceId is pointing to.
element.comment: If headerField is defined, then the variable will be evaluated against the headers that sourceId is pointing to. If path is defined, then the variable will be evaluated against the fixture body that sourceId is pointing to. It is an error to define both headerField and path.

element.name: hint
element.description: Hint help text for default value to enter
element.definition: Displayable text string with hint help information to the user when entering a default value.

element.name: path
element.description: XPath or JSONPath against the fixture body
element.definition: XPath or JSONPath to evaluate against the fixture body. When variables are defined, only one of either expression, headerField or path must be specified.
element.comment: If headerField is defined, then the variable will be evaluated against the headers that sourceId is pointing to. If expression or path is defined, then the variable will be evaluated against the fixture body that sourceId is pointing to. It is an error to define any combination of expression, headerField and path.

element.name: sourceId
element.description: Fixture Id of source expression or headerField within this variable
element.definition: Fixture to evaluate the XPath/JSONPath expression or the headerField against within this variable.
element.comment: This can be a statically defined fixture (at the top of the TestScript) or a dynamically set fixture created by responseId of the `action.operation` element.

element.name: event
element.definition: Identifies specific times when the event occurs.

element.name: repeat
element.description: When the event is to occur
element.definition: A set of rules that describe when the event is scheduled.

constraint.name: tim-9
constraint.message: If there's an offset, there must be a when (and not C, CM, CD, CV)

constraint.name: tim-5
constraint.message: period SHALL be a non-negative value

constraint.name: tim-6
constraint.message: If there's a periodMax, there must be a period

constraint.name: tim-7
constraint.message: If there's a durationMax, there must be a duration

constraint.name: tim-8
constraint.message: If there's a countMax, there must be a count

constraint.name: tim-1
constraint.message: if there's a duration, there needs to be duration units

constraint.name: tim-10
constraint.message: If there's a timeOfDay, there cannot be a when, or vice versa

constraint.name: tim-2
constraint.message: if there's a period, there needs to be period units

constraint.name: tim-4
constraint.message: duration SHALL be a non-negative value

element.name: code
element.description: BID | TID | QID | AM | PM | QD | QOD | +
element.definition: A code for the timing schedule (or just text in code.text). Some codes such as BID are ubiquitous, but many institutions define their own additional codes. If a code is provided, the code is understood to be a complete statement of whatever is specified in the structured timing data, and either the code or the data may be used to interpret the Timing, with the exception that .repeat.bounds still applies over the code (and is not contained in the code).
element.comment: BID etc. are defined as 'at institutionally specified times'. For example, an institution may choose that BID is "always at 7am and 6pm". If it is inappropriate for this choice to be made, the code BID should not be used. Instead, a distinct organization-specific code should be used in place of the HL7-defined BID code and/or a structured representation should be used (in this case, specifying the two event times).

binding.name: TimingAbbreviation
binding.description: Code for a known / defined timing pattern.

element.name: bounds
element.description: Length/Range of lengths, or (Start and/or end) limits
element.definition: Either a duration for the length of the timing schedule, a range of possible length, or outer bounds for start and/or end limits of the timing schedule.

element.name: count
element.definition: A total count of the desired number of repetitions across the duration of the entire timing specification. If countMax is present, this element indicates the lower bound of the allowed range of count values.
element.comment: If you have both bounds and count, then this should be understood as within the bounds period, until count times happens.

element.name: countMax
element.description: Maximum number of times to repeat
element.definition: If present, indicates that the count is a range - so to perform the action between [count] and [countMax] times.

element.name: duration
element.definition: How long this thing happens for when it happens. If durationMax is present, this element indicates the lower bound of the allowed range of the duration.
element.comment: For some events the duration is part of the definition of the event (e.g. IV infusions, where the duration is implicit in the specified quantity and rate). For others, it's part of the timing specification (e.g. exercise).

element.name: durationMax
element.definition: If present, indicates that the duration is a range - so to perform the action between [duration] and [durationMax] time length.
element.comment: For some events the duration is part of the definition of the event (e.g. IV infusions, where the duration is implicit in the specified quantity and rate). For others, it's part of the timing specification (e.g. exercise).

element.name: durationUnit
element.description: s | min | h | d | wk | mo | a - unit of time (UCUM)
element.definition: The units of time for the duration, in UCUM units.

binding.name: UnitsOfTime
binding.description: A unit of time (units from UCUM).

element.name: frequency
element.description: Event occurs frequency times per period
element.definition: The number of times to repeat the action within the specified period. If frequencyMax is present, this element indicates the lower bound of the allowed range of the frequency.

element.name: frequencyMax
element.description: Event occurs up to frequencyMax times per period
element.definition: If present, indicates that the frequency is a range - so to repeat between [frequency] and [frequencyMax] times within the period or period range.

element.name: period
element.description: Event occurs frequency times per period
element.definition: Indicates the duration of time over which repetitions are to occur; e.g. to express "3 times per day", 3 would be the frequency and "1 day" would be the period. If periodMax is present, this element indicates the lower bound of the allowed range of the period length.

element.name: periodMax
element.definition: If present, indicates that the period is a range from [period] to [periodMax], allowing expressing concepts such as "do this once every 3-5 days.

element.name: periodUnit
element.description: s | min | h | d | wk | mo | a - unit of time (UCUM)
element.definition: The units of time for the period in UCUM units.

binding.name: UnitsOfTime
binding.description: A unit of time (units from UCUM).

element.name: dayOfWeek
element.description: mon | tue | wed | thu | fri | sat | sun
element.definition: If one or more days of week is provided, then the action happens only on the specified day(s).
element.comment: If no days are specified, the action is assumed to happen every day as otherwise specified. The elements frequency and period cannot be used as well as dayOfWeek.

element.name: timeOfDay
element.definition: Specified time of day for action to take place.
element.comment: When time of day is specified, it is inferred that the action happens every day (as filtered by dayofWeek) on the specified times. The elements when, frequency and period cannot be used as well as timeOfDay.

element.name: when
element.description: Code for time period of occurrence
element.definition: An approximate time period during the day, potentially linked to an event of daily living that indicates when the action should occur.
element.comment: When more than one event is listed, the event is tied to the union of the specified events.

binding.name: EventTiming
binding.description: Real world event relating to the schedule.

element.name: offset
element.definition: The number of minutes from the event. If the event code does not indicate whether the minutes is before or after the event, then the offset is assumed to be after the event.

element.name: type
element.description: named-event | periodic | data-changed | data-added | data-modified | data-removed | data-accessed | data-access-ended
element.definition: The type of triggering event.

binding.name: TriggerType
binding.description: The type of trigger.

element.name: name
element.description: Name or URI that identifies the event
element.definition: A formal name for the event. This may be an absolute URI that identifies the event formally (e.g. from a trigger registry), or a simple relative URI that identifies the event in a local context.
element.comment: An event name can be provided for all event types, but is required for named events. If a name is provided for a type other than named events, it is considered to be a shorthand for the semantics described by the formal description of the event.

element.name: timing
element.definition: The timing of the event (if this is a periodic trigger).

element.name: data
element.definition: The triggering data of the event (if this is a data trigger). If more than one data is requirement is specified, then all the data requirements must be true.
element.comment: This element shall be present for any data type trigger.

element.name: condition
element.definition: A boolean-valued expression that is evaluated in the context of the container of the trigger definition and returns whether or not the trigger fires.
element.comment: This element can be only be specified for data type triggers and provides additional semantics for the trigger. The context available within the condition is based on the type of data event. For all events, the current resource will be available as context. In addition, for modification events, the previous resource will also be available. The expression may be inlined, or may be a simple absolute URI, which is a reference to a named expression within a logic library referenced by a library element or extension within the containing resource. If the expression is a FHIR Path expression, it evaluates in the context of a resource of one of the type identified in the data requirement, and may also refer to the variable %previous for delta comparisons on events of type data-changed, data-modified, and data-deleted which will always have the same type.

element.name: code
element.definition: A code that identifies the type of context being specified by this usage context.

binding.name: UsageContextType
binding.description: A code that specifies a type of context being specified by a usage context.

element.name: value
element.definition: A value that defines the context specified in this context of use. The interpretation of the value is defined by the code.

binding.name: UsageContextValue
binding.description: A code that defines the specific value for the context being specified.

element.name: url
element.description: Canonical identifier for this value set, represented as a URI (globally unique)
element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this value set when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which at which an authoritative instance of this value set is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the value set is stored on different servers.
element.comment:
Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid: but real http: addresses are preferred. Multiple instances may share the same URL if they have a distinct version.
The determination of when to create a new version of a resource (same url, new version) vs. defining a new artifact is up to the author. Considerations for making this decision are found in [Technical and Business Versions](resource.html#versions).
In some cases, the resource can no longer be found at the stated url, but the url itself cannot change. Implementations can use the [meta.source](resource.html#meta) element to indicate where the current master source of the resource can be found.

element.name: identifier
element.description: Additional identifier for the value set (business identifier)
element.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this value set when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
element.comment: Typically, this is used for identifiers that can go in an HL7 V3 II (instance identifier) data type, and can then identify this value set outside of FHIR, where it is not possible to use the logical URI.

element.name: version
element.description: Business version of the value set
element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the value set when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the value set author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence.
element.comment: There may be different value set instances that have the same identifier but different versions. The version can be appended to the url in a reference to allow a reference to a particular business version of the value set with the format [url]|[version].

element.name: name
element.description: Name for this value set (computer friendly)
element.definition: A natural language name identifying the value set. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alphanumeric type name to ensure that it is machine-processing friendly.A name should be provided unless the value set is a contained resource (e.g. an anonymous value set in a profile). Most registries will require a name.

element.name: title
element.description: Name for this value set (human friendly)
element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the value set.
element.comment: This name does not need to be machine-processing friendly and may contain punctuation, white-space, etc.

element.name: status
element.definition: The status of this value set. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content. The status of the value set applies to the value set definition (ValueSet.compose) and the associated ValueSet metadata. Expansions do not have a state.
element.comment: Allows filtering of value sets that are appropriate for use versus not.See also the [valueset-workflowStatus](extension-valueset-workflowstatus.html) extension for additional status information related to the editorial process.

binding.name: PublicationStatus
binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.name: experimental
element.description: For testing purposes, not real usage
element.definition: A Boolean value to indicate that this value set is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing) and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.comment: Allows filtering of value sets that are appropriate for use versus not.

element.name: date
element.definition: The date (and optionally time) when the value set was created or revised (e.g. the 'content logical definition').
element.comment: Note that this is not the same as the resource last-modified-date, since the resource may be a secondary representation of the value set. Additional specific dates may be added as extensions or be found by consulting Provenances associated with past versions of the resource.

element.name: publisher
element.description: Name of the publisher (organization or individual)
element.definition: The name of the organization or individual that published the value set.
element.comment: Usually an organization but may be an individual. The publisher (or steward) of the value set is the organization or individual primarily responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the value set. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the value set. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.

element.name: contact
element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
element.comment: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number, etc.

element.name: description
element.description: Natural language description of the value set
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the value set from a consumer's perspective. The textual description specifies the span of meanings for concepts to be included within the Value Set Expansion, and also may specify the intended use and limitations of the Value Set.
